content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												While the first words out of most reviewers mouths regarding this game are "metal slug", my impression is that it has taken just as much inspiration from the Megaman games, with a lot of emphasis on careful platforming, learning the patterns of enemies (especially bosses), and choosing the right weapon for the job at hand.Unlike either Metal Slug or Megaman, you go into each mission with a single gun, knife, and set of passive 'bionic mods', plus whatever limited-use equipment you choose to bring or find mid-mission and passive 'proficiencies' which can be changed at will.  This means planning ahead; while at the home base / lobby you will spend money and materials gained during missions to unlock new gun parts, knives, and mods, and outfit yourself as you like;  Do you set yourself up with an optimal plan for your next mission, or just go with what seems fun? Either way, you have a LOT of options to choose from.Another unique quality to Mercenary Kings is the large and non-linear qualities of it's maps;  While each of the different levels gets reused for multiple missions, each one is HUGE with numerous interconnected rooms.  Some missions task you with exploring these maps at large on the look-out for specific enemies or materials, while some give you a clearly marked point to reach (or numerous potential boss locations) and you simply need to navigate a favorable route.Whatever the individual mission objective, it becomes easier and more fun to accomplish with friends.  The co-op REALLY shines when done locally, with two to four friends together in split-screen.  Equally viable is to invite friends online, using steam voice chat or skype for communication.   Public, auto-join online co-op is also available but it's far less ideal, as your only means of communication are a series of quick voice-macros, and there's no way of knowing if the player in charge is thirty missions behind you or thirty missions ahead.   No matter how you choose to do it, the game encourages you to split up and comb different areas of the map, trying to reach or search for your objective, and then meeting up to take on tough bosses together.Speaking of which, the bosses are another area where the game truly shines.  If you've played earlier in the beta, you'll be amazed at how much improvement was made to the game's varying bosses;  each has a wide variety of different attacks and patterns it will follow and each is equally deadly, enough to challenge the most hardcore action-platformer fan.In summary, Mercenary Kings draws inspiration from a LOT of things, but it's as new and original as it is nostalgic, and worth checking out.

												I normally don't write reviews but mercenary kings is an exception for me...So, I've had this game since it's first early access release, but only started playing it now, I went through a couple ranks, and so far I have a positive opinion, let me describe you the gameplayMECHANICS: ISN'T FULLY DISCOVERED FOR ME YET So the core part of the mechanics, is that you have 1 map per 1 rank, the maps are big, in different missions you must roam the map to complete the objectives. That's the missions part, now let's get to the camp part. The camp is a place you roam between the missions, it's split into two parts: 1) The main camp2) Hunting grounds (You can go here to get animals' food, and harvest fruits) The whole point of the camp is that it consists of different members, that do different functions, you can go here to customize your weapons, cook yourself a meal, forge yourself a knife, choose a mission, search for games, customize your tent (Your bragging place, that you can show to different players that join you, here you can have a banner, and ornament, and three of your favourite weapons sets created by youself shown), upgrade armor. Although I didn't play through the game fully yet, this is probably all of the functions that will be available. Posted: June 14, 2015
												When I first saw Mercenary Kings, I became very interested in the game and it looked very exciting to me. The graphics and the gameplay strongly resemble those of the Metal Slug series. There’s the side-scrolling and 2D platforming that old school gamers have appreciated.The plot of Mercenary Kings is about a mercenary who is part of a resistance group that is doing battle with a villainous organization known as The Claw. The narrative quickly becomes irrelevant as you start off in camp and learn to customize your mercenary character. There is no voice acting, so you have to read the dialog text to understand what is really going on. The lack of relevance the narrative has does not bring the game down since gameplay tries to be the strength of the game.Upon playing this game I first realized how awkward the keyboard controls are. There is no mouse to be used in the game, but the keyboard makes the gameplay feel like a drag. I firmly believe that fans of the Metal Slug series would be best advised to use a controller or gamepad to have any fun with this game. Another aspect of the gameplay that feels like a drag is the repetitive nature of the battles with The Claw. You have a limited number of lives and after each death you will have to face the same enemies and this feels quite tedious. Using keyboard controls is difficult when trying to press buttons to shoot, jump, and roll.The graphics are pixelated, but that’s not too bad for a game that’s trying to be an old school, 2D side scroller. If the game had more variety in its levels, the replay value would be exponentially higher. I really wanted to like Mercenary Kings because of its concept of being of resistance fighter battling an organization of villains and the various characters to choose from and customize. Weapons can also be customized so that your mercenary can leave camp for battle with better gear.  I can only recommend this game to those with a game controller or gamepad and do not care much about the quality of the narrative. If you’re a gamer who is accustomed to using the keyboard/mouse combination, I would not recommend Mercenary Kings unless you are willing to commit yourself to playing with a game controller or gamepad.  I give this game a score of 6/10.

content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
It's Just Okay To Be KingMercenary Kings = Paul Robertson - Anamanaguchi + Mega Man + Metal Slug + Cave Story + Repetition + Repetition + Repetition + You get the idea.Featuring Paul Robertson's lovely artwork (you may recognize him from such games as Scott Pilgrim vs. The World), this game glows with a Metal Slug vibe.  However, it would be much more accurate to describe this game as something very similar to Mega Man or Cave Story that is wearing Metal Slug's clothes.The plot consists of...  Um...  Mutant mandrake plants...  Some typical generic bad guys...  Doin' some stuff...  Bad stuff...  Something something elite team of super-juiced mercenaries are gonna kick some♥♥♥♥♥  Okay, so, the story isn't where the game shines.  That's really okay though.  The charm of the characters, the art, and various pop culture and gaming references is going to win you over in that department.A typical session consists of gearing up at the games's hub, Camp Crown, and then selecting a mission to play.  There are several different objective types, however all missions are mostly identical in nature.  Roam around a lovingly-created level, back and forth, for the umpteenth TIME, shooting the same handful of baddies OVER and OVER, picking up endless crafting ingredients, leaping through somewhat sluggish platforming segments, and killing a boss you've probably already fought 3 times before.  All before the time limit runs out.Then you come back to camp.  From here you get into the game's laborious crafting feature.  It is a straightforward collect-a-thon where you exchange various materials found from enemies and chests in order to build new melee weapons, armor, guns or bio-mods.  There is certainly a writhing mass of items to craft, more than I personally ever wanted.  You can create some pretty awesome guns by mixing and matching various parts (receivers, barrels, stocks, etc) and also...  Plenty and plenty of not-so-awesome guns.Rinse.  Repeat.  And repeat.  And repeat.  And repeat.  And repeat.  AND REPEAT.Accept this mission if you... REALLY love action-platformers.  I mean... REALLY love them.  Deeply. Can't get enough of Paul Robertson's bouncing pixelated boobies. Are looking for a content-heavy action game that you can sink a LOT of hours into.Take the first chopper off the island if you... Can't stand grinding.  Seriously, turn back now.  Run. Can't stand backtracking and repetition.  You are going to be running through the same areas OVER and OVER again. Are averse to action platformers with a hint of RPG elements.  Uh, why are you even HERE then?The Bottom LineI started off loving this game.  Then liking it a lot.  Then being okay with it.  Then just desperately wanting it to be over.  Was it worth playing?  Yes, altogther I am glad I played it.  However it definitely wore out its welcome toward the end and became very needlessly frustrating.Example?  Picture running around for 20 minutes trying to complete a boss fight mission, and just as you reach one of the boss RANDOM spawn points, it retreats to another location, leaving you most likely needing to slog back the way you came, kill the dozen or so enemies you just plowed through 1 minute ago, and hop through the maze of spikes, lava, pitfalls, etc.There is a ton of content to this game...  Too much.  I'm not normally the guy to say that, but its like being buried by stuff you can't bother with.  I have about 40 hours into this game but I've probably only unlocked less than a third of the junk to unlock.  The problem is that it can be so absolutely mind-numbing and frustrating to farm for the required ingredients that it's simply not worth it.  For the most part, the only worthwhile crafting you can do are the guns and I didn't even unlock half of those parts.  In theory it's a great system because you can mix and match different parts to create different effect and damage types.  A shotgun that shoots burning birdshot?  Sure.  An SMG that shoots corrosive bouncy balls?  Yep.  A rifle that fires wall-piercing homing bullets?  Indeed.  Unfortunately, MOST of these combinations aren't terribly useful and a lot are just absolutely useless.Another disappointment is that despite being influenced by games such as Metal Slug and Mega Man, there are virtually NO vehicles (with only ONE very mediocre exception).  In fact, there is little to nothing to break the monotony of running back and forth between areas and shooting the same enemies over and over and OVER.*sighDon't get me wrong.  I wanted to love this game.  I ended up liking it and still recommend it...  I just wish a lot of the redundant content was trimmed in favor of BETTER content.  The game could easily be 10 - 20 hours shorter, there could be a third of the crafting recipes that there are.  If getting rid of all that would have meant having some vehicles or missions with truly different mechanics then it would have been well worth it.  There could have been tank driving missions, a submarine boss battle that NEVER HAPPENS, or aerial segments where you shoot down enemies as you hang off the side of lovable ol' Choppy.  Instead, you are repeating a mission that you spent 30 agonizing minutes on because you couldn't find some hidden piece of junk before the timer ran out.The ending leaves open the possibility for a sequel.  I'd love to see one done proper with a lot more variety.  For now...  It's a lovely game with loads of personality and content that just really wears thin after the first 20 hours.

Short ReviewThis game is like if metal slug and megaman had a baby.Mobs follow that set pattern of movement and attack like many platform games, but can still end up killing you. Boss fights are fun but don't expect a Dr. Wiley type of fight think more stage boss than mini or main boss. Game sports lots of weapon types,ammo types, and combinations of the two ,to be bought and used. Missions types though not in large variety provide enough fun and challenge with the paired game play of the environments. Maps are just right for being able to have a lot of gun shootouts though not as many as some might want since some missions take you back to previous maps.Online  MP is probably about the lackluster part in the form of no in game text/voice and no server list.You will randomly connect to someone if they have an open game setup which you can be paired with anyone no matter what rank they are or weapons they have. Other than if someone is jelly on a stick and used up all the shared lives resulting in mission failures this game is one of the few games where it is fun to play with randoms. The game supports up to 4 play local co-op as well. All in all this game is a gem and if you were a metal slug fan or not should be on any shooter fans have/get list.  Full ReviewReally love this game. Its like metal slug meets ironman. I say this because the way the mobs attack you and how they can be smart or dumb reminds me of megaman.The platforming also remind me of megaman there is a good mix or jumping,rolling,shooting,ducking,blocking,etc. Missions in the game are the following, rescue hostage,kill a boss,kill a certain # of a type of mob, kill all the mobs in a certain area, meet with and individual,find and destroy an item/s, or collect a certain amount of a item. Now this might not sound like many mission types but the game throws enough at you to not make the missions boring,at least for me.There are secondary objectives for each mission including secret ones not listed.The reward for the other objectives is typically more money and/or parts. You might say meh to that,but when you want to buy/craft that once piece those harder to find items you might get from  them might be worth your time. Thanks to a scrollable in game map the game makes finding your way to your objective pain free though not all objective types will be marked.Level time can be  a fun time or one that will make you wish for tons more maps.The game has a set number of maps that as you play through the game you will revisit area and unlock larger portions of the areas. This is not a bad thing because you will be more focused on the combat and your objective.Early on in the game it can become a bit tiring to constantly play on the same map,but as you get further along you get a nice variety.The maps themselves are not small and can take you a bit of time to travel around.The game is loaded with tons of guns. You can mix and match all of the pieces to make your own guns provided you have bought the pieces from the camp seller. How that works is the mobs drop material/parts: steel,polymer,wood,lead,etc . You need a certain amount to be able to purchase the part.After that you can use it as much as you want. There are full sets of guns, sniper/full-auto/semi-automatic rifles,machine guns,sub machine gunes,miniguns,shot guns,pistols,and I believe rocket/missile launchers. With each type there are also different ammo types for he different housing including elemental ammo (fire,poison,electric and cold).Now onto the controls, some people have experienced some pains in this area, but there a few guides on how to configure your controls to your hearts desire.If you use a controller that does not seem to work in the game, I suggest a program called Joy2key. I use it for any game that give me grief with my sony controller and it works wonders.Multiplayer in the game is a hit and a miss. No in game voice/text can annoy some people,but everyone in game that I have played with seem to play just fine, just sucks not being able to text chat at the least. There is no server list,no auto rank connections who you connect with will be completely random. All missions can be played by anyone provided the host has the mission chosen. The community for the game seems appropriate(maybe because of the lack of ingame text/voice lol)Game is fun, I have clocked quite a amount of time in it already for the short period of time I have owned the game so far enjoying it a lot. My only wishes are  more maps,more mission types and of course a level editor/mod tools. If you are a shooter fan get the game when you find the price what you desire. I hope mighty9 will be as much fun if not more, need more good platform shooters :3

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
												Imagine what would happen if you took Monster Hunter, and then put it into a semi-retro 2D military setting.That's Mercenary Kings. Mercenary Kings is not Metal Slug and should not be treated as such. It's 2D military Monster Hunter down to the core.What does that mean? Well, for starters, there's a certain set of areas that you'll be redeployed to again and again and again, and larguely these areas will have the same enemies every time, but your goal will be different depending on the mission you take. You might have to gather certain items, destroy a certain object, rescue hostages, clear an area of enemies, kill a boss, and so on. All of these missions also have a time limit, so you can't just take your sweet time looking around, but you'll pretty quickly learn the levels and enemies as you run missions in the areas. All of these are elements pulled right out of Monster Hunter really.What's somewhat different is the crafting. Yes, you go out, gather materials, and them come back to base and cough up some resources and cash to get new equipment. That's the same as Monster Hunter. Where it differs is the depth of customization in your weapon. You get to mix and match parts of your gun to produce different stats and behavior, so you can take a magnum and stick machine gun parts on it if you wish to do so. That said, in reality, what you've really got is a pistol, a machine gun, a burst rifle, a shotgun, and a homing missile launcher, and beyond that you'll just be tweaking stats to manage reload times, reload ease (the game uses an active reload system that can give you a 10% damage boost if you do it perfectly), accuracy, damage, ammo capacity (before reloading, you have infinite ammo otherwise), fire rate, weight, and bullet propeties (homing, elemental, bursting into smaller projectiles, scatter shot, large size, and rebounding). It's actually pretty simple, but there's certainly some joy in tweaking your weapon to suit the situation or match your play style.Now let's talk about enemies. The enemies in the game all follow very simple behavior patterns, including the bosses, and there's not generally many of them on screen at once. The game certainly has some difficulty when you first encounter enemies and don't know what to expect, but once you learn them it does become somewhat repetative. After all, you're going to be fighting the same enemies on the same levels quite a bit. Nonetheless, I certainly find some joy in being able to rush through levels that I once had difficulty with. That said, as said, the bosses are pretty simple too, so while this game share a whole lot in common with Monster Hunter, don't expect to get the same feeling of accomplishment from downing a tough big bad, because there's nothing quite that scale here.In any case, the game is pretty fun, but just keep in mind that it's really a Monster Hunter styled game, and that means you're going to spend a whole lot of time looking at the same scenery and fighting the same enemies. If you want an arcade action game with a bunch of hectic levels, this isn't it.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Do you like Metal Slug? Do you like Monster Hunter? Do you like Paul Robertson?Yes, yes, and yes, get this game. Finally finished after being worked on and tempered for quite a while, this game is the best we can hope for a 2d mash-up of shoot 'em ups and grind 'em ups. ==THE GOOD==Amazing spritework from Paul Robertson, or at least designs. Whether or not he did the full animating, it's still a very impressive job. The intro is stellar for setting up an actiony arcade game.Quick fun and good multiplayer capability. Grab some friends and rampage around! Loot is shared, where one person needs to pick it up and the rest of your group gets the rewards, so having someone branch off to look for supplies isn't a bad thing. Plus, with reviving teammates if they get in over their head, and no friendly fire, having a partner helps.Gun customization. Slap together your weapon with multiple options. There are sets, yes, and some parts don't work so well with others, but for the most part you're free to craft your gun with whatever you grab.==THE BAD==The grind. It's not as terrible as some games can be, Monster Hunter or certain other games considered. But to make some weapons, mods, or ornaments, be prepared to run a mission well into the double digit numbers. Completionists would do well to have patience for this game.Enemy repetition. Not until about the halfway point in the game do enemies become very varied. Not a huge problem though.Ultimately, great purchase and fun game.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2015
												This game is almost good, but even after only a couple missions, I can see where the bad reviews are coming from. The shooting mechanics are decent, but not perfect. For instance, you can't shoot upwards while moving, which feels unintuitive and confining. There are also some irritating things about the way the menus work that should clearly be changed, but this stuff is minor compared to the main flaws...As much as I am growing sick of games about collecting and crafting, I think I would actually enjoy collecting materials in this game, if it weren't for the fact that enemies respawn in EXACTLY the same spot. And I don't mean the same spot every time you play the mission, or even every 30 seconds, I mean as soon as their spawn is off screen. This does two terrible things: it forces you to manage the screen's position or risk being mobbed by the same enemies repeatedly, and it makes material collection extremely trivial. For example, the first mission I played was in the hunting grounds, to acquire two pelts. This doesn't mean exploring the map like it should. What it means is knowing where one fox spawns, then repeatedly trying to kill it before it RUNS FIVE FEET AND DISAPPEARS FOR NO REASON. Then I move to one side and run back and do the same thing again until the mission ends.If I can bring myself to continue the game, I can't imagine changing my opinion later on. As others have said, this is a game that's ultimately about grinding for materials and crafting, but that one single design choice completely undermines that. Enemies need to spawn in random locations, and they probably need to NOT RESPAWN AT ALL during a single mission. Even if the overall amount of content in the game is limited, I believe those two changes would make the game infinitely more playable than it is. As things stand, I wouldn't really recommend this to anyone.If the game could be heavily redesigned from what it is, I could see it improving in one of two ways. The first would be to have more authored content, distinct levels that were meant to be played in a linear way from start to finish, but could be repeated to collect more ingredients, money, etc. In Metal Slug, I played those levels over and over for no reason except that they were fun. By comparison, I get bored of a Mercenary Kings level before I even finish it once, because it's so stagnant.The second option would've been to move towards heavier randomization, perhaps procedural areas that would mean not repeating content at all, but could perhaps result in less interesting levels. But even in its current state, the only thing that needs to change to vastly improve this game is the enemy spawns, which seems like a totally doable change to me, though it'd be a fair amount of work to rebalance objectives and alter the enemy spawns to suit it. But IMO, it needs to be done or the game is not worth playing. Which is a shame, because there is a lot of stuff to like about it.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Mercenary Kings was one of the most disappointing games I've played in a while.  It looks great and the premise gives off the vibe that it's going to play like a Metal Slug, Contra or any other fast-paced 2D action shooter.  It doesn't and almost every aspect of the gameplay is poor.You'll notice immediately the intentional jump delay.  I don't know why the devs were so tied into this mechanic, it's terrible in this type of game.  You can get away with deliberate jumping in some titles, but not this one.  The jump delay makes the game feel so off.  MK also has reloading.  Why?  I don't know and having to reload constantly brings nothing positive to the game.  There's also the issue that you have to press down to pick up items, and you'll have to pick up items constantly and it breaks any flow the game manages to create.  I wish the whole crafting angle wasn't even a thing because it doesn't appeal to me in the least and from I've read, it's not any good even if you're into crafting.Supposedly the game is super repetitive and grindy as well, but I didn't last long enough to find out.  If you're looking for some fasted-paced 2D shooting action on PC, you're much better off with the Metal Slug ports, even though DotEmu didn't exactly do a great job on them.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												First of all, let me say the game is really pretty. It has a great retro aesthetic that moves and feels like an SNK classic. The most obvious comparison being Metal Slug of course. The music is good as well and captures that same era perfectly and is generally catchy and unobtrusive. Missions are boring and styled after MMO/RPG cliches of kill so many of this, gather so many of that, etc. and the big kicker is you can't double up on missions. Each one must be completed separately which wouldn't be unbearable if the game didn't re-use the -exact- same map for 10 or so missions. Meaning that you see the same map, with the same infinity re spawning enemies, far too much. Especially since there isn't much in the way of enemy variety nor are enemies challenging or satifying to eliminate. Even bosses are a bit of a bore considering the slower paced nature of the combat and the GoW style active reload system. Which in a better developed or more fully realized combat system would be extremely satisfying. The game also makes a big deal out of the different gun parts and plethora of combinations possible but the sad truth is most are pretty worthless and to be frankly honest a base nearly unmodified pistol will do just as well as a custom designed toilet/saxophone/chaingun. Which sort of misses the entire point doesn't it? All in all what could have been an excellent 2D  hybrid of Borderlands/Metal Slug/Contra became a tired chore of repetition. Maybe the dev team will go on to bigger and better things, I can only hope.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2013
												If you like Metal Slug- this is WAY better. All the old school charm, but none of the crappy controls. You get to build your own custom guns, upgrade your merc, and they didn't phone in the level content. I'm looking forward to trying the multiplayer.EDIT: Nevermind. This game is a chore. The gun thing is fine, but there is not as much customization as you might think. Most combinations just make crap guns. In order to use special ammo, you pretty much have to use parts wou may not want or that may take away aspects of the gun you like. I suppose this was done to keep people from making caustic longrang auto shotguns or something. The reload mechanic is alright. I still love the art and the gameplay is tight, but man the boss fights generally suck. Not the challenge or the pattern or the attacks! All that is fine! The problem is that they change locations. You pretty much get the first encounter to defeat them and if you don't smack them completely, in the first go, they flee to another part of the map, immediately spawn (if someone is there or not) and start going through their pattern. By the time you get to the location where they spawned, you get a few prescious seconds to attack them before they flee again. Now, you could leave the game running where they last spawned and eventually they will come back to that location, but that is boreing. So basically, it is a lame dynamic that greatly detracts from the game.This is not just one boss- but one boss they use over an over again.Also, the massive amount of levels are mostly repeats. I could have done with a more cogent/crafted set of story driven levels, one leading to the other, or an open world, or a big overworld map, but this constant revisiting of places I just wooped up on and finding them completely repopulated with bosses that flee and hostages and all that . . . jeez. This little war is being severely mismanaged. I understand that he is cloning soldiers and repopulating the levels, but come on! The same levels over and over again? Why not hit the cloning facility ASAP! Cut off supplies to the facility, sabotage the AA guns, drop some mercs in over the wall with that heli (or use a teleporter) and  de-CLAW the general! You have time to think about these things as you are running through a level for the 16th time chasing a coward in a jet. The fix? Make more of the repeat levels optional and make the bosses only spawn in their next location when a player actually shows up there. content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												At first glance, Mercenary Kings looks like a classic side scrolling shoot-em-up, a la Metal Slug. This is mostly due to Paul Robertson's (of Scott Pilgrim fame) beautiful pixel art. Though if this is what you're expecting, you may be disappointed. Instead, Mercenary King's hectic action is much more akin to classic Mega Man, requiring precise shooting and platforming. This is augmented with fully customizable weapons, allowing you to build custom killing machines. For example, you can attach a sniper rifle barrel and a submachine gun magazine to a magnum pistol and arm it with enemy-seeking missiles.What starts out as an arcade-style excuse plot rapidly becomes a very compelling story. Including mindless clones, body horror, and a dog in power armor. The game is full of humor without relying too much on it's subtle 80's film and arcade references, and the characters are compelling enough to make you actually worry when they're imperiled.The game can be played solo, but supports up to four player local and online co-op. I set the game up and got a few friends over to blast through the first 20 or so missions, and it's an absolute joy to strategize, team up against bosses, and explore the large and secret-laden maps.Using a Monster Hunter style drop system for the materials to craft your knives, gun parts, and biomods, the game rewards replaying missions. If you get bored of seeing the same enemies and maps multiple times, this may not be a game for you. In classic arcade style, almost every enemy will have 'pallette swaps' that introduce new elemental attacks and strategies.I've put a little over 50 hours into the game already, and I've been having a blast optimising my weapon builds, exploring and memorizing levels, and blowing away CLAW forces.One of your guns is a cat with it's own tiny shotgun.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												If you are looking at this, buy this game.Seriously, if you have interest enough to be looking at this page, I assure you this game will deliver. It will. It just will.Mercenary Kings is, at its core, a perfect blend of Contra, Metal Slug, and Monster Hunter, all represented with stunningly crafted sprites and an artstyle that is just amazing. The gameplay is satisfying and precise like Contra, from the shooting to the platforming and the controls. On top of that, it has the addictive collecting and crafting of Monster Hunter. You will find yourself unable to stop as you want to collect more items to personalize your character.The personalization is top notch. Weapon customization is absurdly awesome. There are tons of options to mix and match to create a gun that really fits your play-style, and all of them are very well-balanced. You could spend hours just trying out all of the combinations to see what you like best.The game is currently in alpha, but it has a level of polish like no other early access game I've seen. It is fully playable with seemingly no bugs in sight. Its truly astonishing - I really feel they could have called the game finished already, but nevertheless they are still cranking out updates for it, so don't let that "early access" label scare you off.All in all, I was pleasantly surprised at just how fun this game was. Playing this game has actually gotten me to say "Wow, this is fun" out loud, something that not many games can do. I was hoping for some fun, Contra-styled platforming - and this game did more than deliver.

												Great game! First of all I have'nt played metal slug "don't scream at me" but I can still relate this game to monster hunter which I have played. The game has amazing audio and the art style is great. I never say "this music again" or "that drone is so annoying". The concept is nice but the story is meh. You go on missions with various objectives which sometimes can be unclear but don't give up. As you complete missions you advance on to new tiers that unlock new gun parts, knives, and progress you through the story. The best part is creating your own weapons. The wepon parts are divided into 6 parts, reciever, stock, barrel, magazine, sight, and ammo. Also there are different types of weapons like smgs, shotguns, snipers, magnums, and so on and so forth. You can mix and match or you can make a 100% shotgun to craft unique ammo only for shotguns. If you get 100% or over on a weapon type you can craft new ammo for it. And multiplayer too! There is 4 player co-op and it is a ton more fun with friends. Sometimes this game can get rather boring though, as many of the missions are rince and repeat but it keeps me going because I am always looking to improve my gear and unlocking new areas. Over all this game is great and highly recommend this game to anyone who likes platformers.  7/10

												Okay, I think I have a decent grasp of this game to where I can actually write something about it~ :3This game is amazing if you're a fan of Metal Slug-type platformers.  It has amazing graphics done by the talented Paul Robertson, who did all the graphic art for the Scott Pilgrim videogame, as well as making many entertaining videos featuring his sprite-work. I personally donated to the Kickstarter of this game because I heard that guy was going to be in charge of the graphics team.I'm currently reviewing the build based off of the early access version, so I don't know if some of the issues I've noticed will even make it to the final cut, as this game updates almost every other day.  I've noticed the AI can be really dumb at some parts, but it does not detract from the game, because there have been dumb AI's in almost any game ever made.  This game is one of those games where you can end up spending a lot of time without realizing you just spent a lot of time doing things.Early on you're basically just grinding for parts while learning the game and getting a feel for the controls.  You start out at an early rank, and by completing mission objectives such as gathering x amount of items, hunting x person down, freeing x hostages, or killing a boss, you slowly begin to branch out into the meaty bits of the game.  Now the fun part is as you begin rescuing key people, they get added into your camp and you are allowed to use all those parts you have been gathering to upgrade your character, whether it be their guns, knife, or special perks.  This is where the game detracts from the Metal Slug genre, and into its own special category, as you can mix and match gun parts to create a weapon that you love to use.  Each part usually has a drawback, but they also usually have an advantage too, so it evens out (so no gun combination is really overpowered as far as I can see currently).Instead of finding power-ups like in Metal Slug, you just create your own weapon of choice.I have not tried the multiplayer yet, but it sounds like it could be really fun as long as latency isn't too much of an issue.  The game looks and plays beautifully and it's not even currently out of beta yet.  I would highly recommend this game to anyone that is looking for something different to play.  Especially if you like grinding for parts like in PSO or Sonic Adventure 2, but this time with Metal Slug gameplay.(I also don't recommend this to people who don't have an xbox controller, as the keyboard controls felt really awkward when I was playing it not at home, but it could work)

content:
Posted: July 26, 2013
												Not a recommendation exactly, but more like my early thoughts on this pre-release game.Art style is like Metal Slug, which is what drew me in initially. However, it plays more like Mega Man. You have a life bar so you don't have to play perfectly, and there's a little more platforming than a Slug game. No insta-death traps or pits, which is nice. It's got that Gears of War reload action bar; can add tension or be a distraction in the heat of the moment. All around, gameplay's pretty solid if not easy to a Mega Man veteran.100 stages is misleading; it's really 100 missions spread over a handful of branching-path areas that are reused. You'll see the same zones multiple times. Good for getting familiar with the terrain, but revisiting the same places gets repetitive.Downed enemies can drop materials that're used for gun/knife/perk crafting. And there's lots of gun parts to craft. Some are interesting, others seem nearly identical stat-wise. Gathering rare mats can kinda suck, but it gives you more to do in-game than just run 'n gun all the time.Both local and online multiplayer available.  Haven't tried either one, but hear it's good.  When picked up, crafting mats are given to everyone (though the resultant item can be different from player-to-player due to individual perks) so no ninja looting required.There are bugs that need squashing. They'll be tweaking and adjusting gameplay/menus/UI. There's a lack of challenge for some.  It's missing a compelling reason to keep playing besides a basic story and unlocking new craftables.  But in an unfinished state, it's not bad and will only get better. Can't fully recommend it yet, nor would I discourage anyone to try it out if they like this style of game.  At the very least, it's worth keeping an eye on for the future.#1 tip: Utilize dat map!!#2 tip: Magazine size affects your gun's power. Big mags, low damage. Small mags, death machine that needs constant reloading.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												"Borderlands, Contra, and Gears of War had a baby - they called it Mercenary Kings and it's pretty. Now go away, I wanna keep playing it."Mercenary Kings is hand drawn pixel art at its finest, brought to you by the same folks who rendered the Scott Pilgrim game. The art alone is enough to gawk at, making expert use of animations, sprites, silhouettes and the like. What's important about it, and why it deserves such attention, is because that EVERY pixel was lovingly and knowingly placed to give Mercenary Kings a very distinct look and feel.The plus side is that when you start putting that much effort into every pixel, you start to care about where they're all going - the controls in this game are tight and responsive, especially if you play with a game controller. Layered on top of this are several fun and exhaustive features, including but not limited to active reloading, collectibles, and a unique brand of rocket jumping that involves a minigun.Where Mercenary Kings falls short, however, is in its pacing and length. The game has a lot to offer, A LOT, and one might even argue it has a bit too much. Grinding drops for better gear isn't always a bad thing, but it can get tedious mission after mission during the long campaign of the game. What's more, the formula doesn't change much over its course, so in time the game itself can feel like a grind.However, all in all, this is action gaming done correctly. While the metroidvania genre only recognizes two games, it's important to know that Contra, Megaman, and more added a worthy third style of game to the mix that involves a few more guns - Mercenary Kings is the pinnacle of that.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												I wish I could recommend this game, but I really, really can't.  The controls are sluggish, jumping is floaty and aggravatingly unresponsive, weapons either take too long to kill something or spend too much time reloading, and the entire experience is a slow-moving slog.The underlying issue with this game is that EVERYTHING is designed to take far too long or is intentionally tedious.  There are many missions with mission timers 25 minutes longer or more, with the goal of just scouring each and every room to find weapon parts.  If this sounds like MMO fetch quests, you're right, and these missions are just as grindy, made even worse by the fact that you will do them on maps where you have ALREADY been through the map 4-5 times already.Movement speed?  Way too slow, even with light weapons.  Even the firing mode is lousy, giving you a pathetic 4 firing directions instead of the bog-standard 360-degree joystick- or mouse-based method that has been around for decades now.  The view frame is much too zoomed-in, meaning you frequently can't see where you're going, causing you to blunder into enemies or traps, as well as triggering incredibly excessive amounts of off-screen enemy respawns.  Map layouts range from mediocre to aggravating, with a great many paths hanging just over your head that you can't access unless you walk halfway across the map to a ladder or something.The customizable weapons system SEEMED interesting at first, but it's both poorly balanced and based on grinding out items to get the items to make decent parts.  Machine guns have low damage and high magazines, making dealing with many standard enemies, and especially several bosses that have only limited vulnerability, very tedious.  Shotguns deal huge damage and have low magazines, with their "balance" mechanism being semi-auto firing; this means you spend HUGE amounts of time mashing the fire button, which is just plain ridiculous when they could have easily just left the shotguns as full-auto weapons for the simple sake of ENJOYMENT.  On top of that, many of the parts look different, but have minimal performance differences.  And even the bullet types are blocked off by forcing you to have the right level of compatibility with your current weapon parts, so custom weapon diversity is severely curtailed if you ever want to use different ammo types.There are also dozens of missions, but without much actual variety.  Go fetch these crafting items, kill X soldiers in area Y, destroy this thing, and hostage rescue is about it, with maps recycled CONSTANTLY.  There is a severe mission bloat, with you doing the exact same things over and over and over again on the same levels to make the game seem longer/bigger than it is.The perk system is also pretty poor.  Unless you enjoy scouring recycled maps for boss/target locations, you'll just end up slapping up on the perk that puts targets on your map, which, in other games, would be part of the standard game design anyway and you wouldn't need any sort of silly perk to see them.  The roll maneuver is almost entirely useless until you can get a perk to give it invincibility which, again, should've been a completely standard thing anyway.  I could honestly go on, but it would just be redundant.  The artwork looks solid, but the game itself is mediocre and entirely third-rate, suffering from a whole raft of fun-robbing design choices.  Basically, unless you legitimately enjoy grinding out item collection for MMO-esque "make this weapon that is sliiiightly better than your current one", skip this game and just get the Metal Slug games.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												The Good:- I grew up playing NES and SNES platformers, and so I truly enjoy seeing this art style popularized again. For what Mercenary Kings offers in terms of gameplay, the art style matches up nicely and makes the game feel cohesive.  - Mercenary Kings offers a plethora of weapon customization options. The abundance of options enticed me to spend hours mixing and matching parts across different weapon categories in order to perfect a gun suited to my specific play style. - Surprisingly, the game has a entertaining story with multiple twists. Mercenary Kings was definitely improved by this because it justified playing through the absurd amount of story missions (112 unique missions in total) in order to reach the conclusion.  The Bad:- I loathed how Mercenary Kings portrayed their women antagonists and protagonists. The overt objectification only served to reflect that the designers are out of touch with where modern audiences are in terms of gender relations.- The mission structures, goals, and levels in Mercenary Kings are extremely repetitive. While the goal might change between missions, you’re frequently placed in the same level to achieve this objective. Additionally, the objectives also lacked diversity - for example, often you’re collecting an object, neutralizing an enemy, or capturing a specific enemy.  Unquestionably, the central problem of Mercenary Kings is quantity over quality. In order to acquire the necessary number of parts to construct banners, ornaments, gun parts, knife parts, and mods you’ll have to grind far too much. Final Verdict:Mercenary Kings looks like a Metal Slug clone (this is actually the reason I bought it without first researching the game), but it is far from that. The gameplay is much slower, and the RPG elements take center stage as opposed to a straightforward shoot ‘em up action adventure. I can’t recommend this game at full price. I purchased this game for 1.00 (humblebundle), and I had fun, but after the first ten to twenty hours it became an endeavor to simply complete the game. However, because of what I paid, I didn’t feel cheated. 6/10.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												It's not Metal Slug, so let's get that out of the way first. Mercenary Kings (MK) does borrow a lot from SNK's long running series (like rescuing hostages that say "Thank You!" after or the general look of the game), but it also borrows ideas from other games, like Metroid, Metal Gear Solid, and Contra. MK is best played through local co-op, at least so far to me. I haven't played it online with other folks, just my girlfriend and so far we're hooked. For a $10 game (on sale), I've squeezed 20 hours of gameplay out of it and we're not even half way done with all of the objectives. We're having a blast playing this -- splitting up on missions to accomplish multiple objectives efficiently or teaming together to take down a nasty boss. It's very fun.The music is really catchy as hell, too. Has that NES/Genesis vibe to it and you'll be humming the songs in this game at work every day because they get stuck in your head. The art direction is really nice, too. If you liked Scott Pilgrim The Game, this is up your alley. Even at full price of $20, MK is worth the admission. If you have a friend to play with, do not think twice about purchasing.

												Mercenary Kings is a 2D co-op pixel shooter, reminiscent of Contra or, more accurately, Metal Slug. content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Everyone making Metal Slug comparisons and judging it on those grounds went into this with the wrong expectations. Neither the steam page nor any gameplay video, now or prior to its full release, ever promoted this game as being similar to Metal Slug.With that out of the way, let's come out and say what it is: this is Mega Man x Monster Hunter. The controls, level design, enemies, and gameplay are all explicitly cribbed from Mega Man, while the mission design, gear crafting progression, and boss mechanics are lifted from Monster Hunter. You accept a mission, from something as mundane as killing a couple mooks, to hunting two of a particular boss, and you're dropped into the level with the supplies you've brought with you. Certain supplies can be gathered in the field, as can materials, and you traverse the rather sizable level completing your objective, after which you return to base, where you resupply, craft guns, knives, and skills, and select a new mission. Much like Monster Hunter, this game encourages cooperative play, so rev up the online or bring along a friend, or you're quickly going to find yourself frustrated by how long later missions take to complete.If that sounds at all appealing to you, by all means, pick it up. You could easily squeeze at least 20 hours out of it, and it's an excellent couch co-op title.

												It's not Metal Slug, so let's get that out of the way first. For a $10 game (on sale), I've squeezed 20 hours of gameplay out of it and we're not even half way done with all of the objectives. We're having a blast playing this -- splitting up on missions to accomplish multiple objectives efficiently or teaming together to take down a nasty boss. It's very fun.The music is really catchy as hell, too. Has that NES/Genesis vibe to it and you'll be humming the songs in this game at work every day because they get stuck in your head. The art direction is really nice, too. If you liked Scott Pilgrim The Game, this is up your alley. Even at full price of $20, MK is worth the admission. If you have a friend to play with, do not think twice about purchasing.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
												The Good:- I grew up playing NES and SNES platformers, and so I truly enjoy seeing this art style popularized again. For what Mercenary Kings offers in terms of gameplay, the art style matches up nicely and makes the game feel cohesive.  - Mercenary Kings offers a plethora of weapon customization options. The abundance of options enticed me to spend hours mixing and matching parts across different weapon categories in order to perfect a gun suited to my specific play style. - Surprisingly, the game has a entertaining story with multiple twists. Mercenary Kings was definitely improved by this because it justified playing through the absurd amount of story missions (112 unique missions in total) in order to reach the conclusion.  The Bad:- I loathed how Mercenary Kings portrayed their women antagonists and protagonists. The overt objectification only served to reflect that the designers are out of touch with where modern audiences are in terms of gender relations.- The mission structures, goals, and levels in Mercenary Kings are extremely repetitive. While the goal might change between missions, you’re frequently placed in the same level to achieve this objective. Additionally, the objectives also lacked diversity - for example, often you’re collecting an object, neutralizing an enemy, or capturing a specific enemy.  Unquestionably, the central problem of Mercenary Kings is quantity over quality. In order to acquire the necessary number of parts to construct banners, ornaments, gun parts, knife parts, and mods you’ll have to grind far too much. Final Verdict:Mercenary Kings looks like a Metal Slug clone (this is actually the reason I bought it without first researching the game), but it is far from that. The gameplay is much slower, and the RPG elements take center stage as opposed to a straightforward shoot ‘em up action adventure. I can’t recommend this game at full price. I purchased this game for 1.00 (humblebundle), and I had fun, but after the first ten to twenty hours it became an endeavor to simply complete the game. However, because of what I paid, I didn’t feel cheated. 6/10.

Posted: August 1, 2015
												To summarize right away; 8/10, it's fun and is beautifully crafted. Defeinitely gets repetitive quickly, though.  Right away this game kinda jumps back to some older gameplay styles, it's highly intuitive. It teaches you some of the base mechanics right away in the intro, but it doesn't really give you the whole bag, it kinda makes you figure the rest out, which I personally enjoyed. There were a lot of "I can do that?!" moments throughout gameplay. The platforming works really well, and the controls feel responsive enough. The design is a real eye catch, everything is gorgeous and so lovelingly animated. It's highly reminiscent of Metal Slug in a lot of ways. The actually gameplay feels a lot like MS, and the atmosphere is similar in a lot of ways too. I actually started to pick up a few silly references to MS, and other games similar, including Metal Gear Solid.Boss fights at first were kind of a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ though once I got the swing of things, they again became very intuitive and doable. They brought a Monster Hunter feel to it in how you had to track the bosses around the map.Last good note I'm giving is the weapon crafting system. That♥♥♥♥♥♥s fun. Nothing gives a more personal feel to combat when you yourself had to scrounge up the pieces and put together your own weapon. Their are so many different pieces, and it's all together a very nice touch. It could have easily been replaced with weapon drops and no one would have noticed, and that shows the care put into making this.Now onto the negative: It's REALLY ♥♥♥♥ing repetitive. You have set stages per rank of mission and you keep going back to those same maps continuously. This was kind of my deal on Peace Walker, though it wasn't nearly as bad there since the maps cycled more frequently. Here, you end up dealing with the same map per chapter. Last thing I'm gonna mention, I saw a few rags on storyline. I kinda didn't feel like the story was all that important here, given you're a mercenary. The characters all had a bit of personality, and your actions felt like they mattered to the world, so it was good to me. To conclude, 8/10 would recommend.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												now that the game's finally out i can make another 1-sentence summary of it instead of actually reviewing it (but nah I feel like this game deserves some unbiased nitpicking instead of me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on it and leaving)it's a game that really wanted to be contra mixed with monster hunter. It feels like the developers played and loved MH, but in the end didn't truly know why the features in MH made it what it is.When the kickstarter first went up one of the big things I laughed at was the fact that they wrote "add in a little monster hunter and you got our game" or something like that when describing the features. Now that the game's out, it's not immediately apparent, but it's true. Most criticizable aspects of the game stem from the fact that it wants to emulate Monster Hunter.The missions are stale, primarily because they use the exact same 3 modes that MH has: kill X small enemies, gather X items on the field, or kill X boss monster. Rarely, the game will also have "talk to this NPC" quests also but that's negligible since they're just preludes to one of the other types of missions. They're meant to introduce the level by having you navigate it for specific area.Additionally, upgrades and bonuses are gained through the same general "luck of the drop" system Monster Hunter is both rewarded and criticized for. This system is in place in Monster Hunter because the monster duels are not only fun but also dangerous enough to make players want to play it safe and stick to familiar tactics at first. Repeating the boss a couple times for certain drops, or changing weapon or strategy to try to get a drop that doesn't match your playstyle, are ways of making Monster Hunter more enjoyable. You get to see how the monsters are designed to act differently in different situations, plus with the tight combat already in place, it's a thrill either way.That's not in Mercenary Kings. in MK, you dodge the same 3-5 attacks over and over, shoot the weak point (usually the back) of a boss, and eventually it goes down or is left open to capture. These nuances are found in MH as well, but aren't put there for the same reason. The lack of health bars in Monster Hunter is to encourage awareness in the player. They want you to look for signs of weakness, signs of battle damage in the creature you're hunting. a health bar would ruin the point of that. In Merc Kings, the enemy constantly flashes bright red when they're injured enough to be captured, so with zero subtlety, it just says you're 2/3rds done already.Monster drops in MH were to indicate playstyle in a way. You could only get the tail of a monster if you were attacking its back. You could only get the horns if you actually were able to smash the horns off with a kill, or if you could capture it with the horns perfectly intact still (meaning no face hits). MK is just pure percentile chance rewarding you for the kill.I don't HATE the game, because I still enjoy the simplistic gameplay and item grinding to some extent, but I think it's fine to like a game while also knowing it's full of developer mistakes.For $10 I think it's a perfectly dandy 2D platformer monster hunter knockoff with full online co-op.

												Short Version Below, just skip to PROs and CONs:I picked this little gem up when it went on sale. I figured "Hey, it looks like fun, it's multiplayer, and it looks similar to Metal Slug" In some regards it is, but in others, it's a whole other beast. First, I'll draw the similarities.When you first start up Mercenary Kings, you'll notice, "Hey, this plays a lot like Metal Slug" (if you're familiar with the series). Controls are a little strange at first, though I'd recommend changing them, but once you get down to the nitty-gritty stabby-shooty, you don't seem to notice as much. There's the familiar, arcade-style run-and-gun type gameplay that you'd expect from the screenshots, but what really makes this game unique is the differences from which the game breaks the stereotype.The crafting system is extensive that sometimes it can be overwhelming, but if you're the type that loves to tinker around and figure out what works best (which varies, depending on the mission), or if you fancy yourself a virtual gunsmith, then you will love this crafting system. A few RPG elements are added in that there are a few stats to keep in balance as you prepare for each mission, but other than that, there's not too much else to the game. I do, however, really like the way multiplayer (both local, on one machine, or over the Internet) is handled. From the in-game base camp, players can join their friends or find other players online and team up to accomplish missions seamlessly (think drop-in/drop-out style, but only for this one area).In short:PROS:Excellent and fun selection of weaponsFamiliar gameplay style feels freshSeamless multiplayer matchmaking - You can find a team rather quickly, and if they leave you, there's no penalties to you. (A big bonus!)Lots of pew pew pewCONS:Controls can be a bit awkward at first. I felt like a noob who never played arcade games beforeCrafting system can be a mite overwhelming for players who just want to jump into the gameMissions can be repetitive if you're grinding for crafting materialsOverall, I highly recommend this game, it was worth every penny.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												My unfortunate first negative review on steam.  Bought this game with the intentions of playing with a friend, but even from the get-go (And all the way up till the end boss) I had nagging issues that continued to hamper my experience with the game.The foremost offender is the incredibly awkward controlling.  Characters react based on how heavy their weapons are, but even with light equipment, jumps can be incredibly pixel percise with a slow reaction to pressing the jump button.   This becomes incredibly annoying on bosses that rush from side to side on the screen, and you think you press the button early enough only to have the wind up time keep you from clearing your foe.  Aiming can also be an issue when trying to shoot smaller enemies that move through the air (Not to mention chase you after the camera changes and moves them off screen), theres no way to shoot diagonally which means you'll have to constantly run under vertical enemies to hit them or lead them into your shots.As you get further in, you notice that the mission strcutres all fall into the same few catagories:  Find stuff or kill/capture stuff.  It becomes more tedious in the latter half of the game as the levels expand, leaving you and your friend(s) to traverse large boring structures with occasionally respawning enemies that even with high health and defense items, can still tear away large portions of your health.  And with limited carrying space for items, trying to heal in our outside the hospital zones can be incredibly tedious as there's no ingame way to speed up the hospital healing process.  I suppose thats why most missions have extra long times (Anywhere between 15-30 minutes usually), but it just bogs down the experience.  The bosses are far to repetitive too, having to face the same lot multiple times across the games ranked missions and an occaisonal unique boss at the end of most ranks.The weapon crafting is an excercise in patience, having to always constantly change out one gun trait for another, taking time in order to get anywhere close to a satisfying weapon.  More so, since the crafting system relies on the materials you find in the stage, you may be forced to run back into earlier levels and hope that enemies respawn AND drop the items you're looking for.If I'm pressed to say anything positive about it, the presentation has a nice psuedo-Metal Slug/SNK feel thats still unique enough to be a full rip off, and the music often catchy.  But thats not enough to get a recommendation here, its just not fleshed out enough to be fun either by yourself or with friends.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2014
												This is a great game that unfortunately falls into the curse of "gets good a couple hours in". It takes a while for the mission structure and crafting to click, and not all the missions are super well designed; map checking is often required (but easy), and the map is useless for a couple of off-beat missions.The real meat of the game is building and customizing gun parts, but unfortunately since this requires materials, you can't jump right into making a gun, you have to play the first few levels, which are basically tutorials. And even once you can make a few gun parts, the guns don't get really fun until you start adding elements and special bullet types (freezing bullets, shotguns, bouncing bullets, homing missiles that pierce walls!) I feel the game would have been much better received if this were explained better and you got some materials to play with out of the starting gate instead of having to use the starter pistol for a few levels.This is, however, a great chill-out game, and if you enjoy grinding materials and crafting there's plenty of that to do. People call it Monster Hunter crossed with Metal Slug, but the gameplay is a bit more like Mega Man (with a single, customized gun rather than switchable energy-based weapons). Bosses roam certain maps sort of like Monster Hunter, though the crafting and mission structure are really where the Monster Hunter influence shows. Unlike Metal Slug you have health so you don't die in one hit, but health is still a fairly precious resource.The gameplay is surprisingly deep; gun weight affects how high you jump and how fast you move, you have consider how all of your gun's parts sum up into a good (or awful) weapon, and there's a bit of inventory management as you can only carry a couple healing/progression enabling items (but you can call for a couple more items mid-level).Co op gameplay is great--all players get all resources collected, so there's no fighting over drops. This also means playing online with randoms isn't quite as annoying as say Borderlands 2, because no one can swipe your rare drops.

												Mercenary Kings is a bad game, it has terrible and awkward controls (even after remapping them) and suffers from very bad gameplay. The main point of the game is to fire your weapon, but wait you cannot fire your weapon up or down while moving nor can you fire diagonally. Lastly, the game becomes extremely boring and grindy due to the level/rank progression system which forces you to repeat levels over and over until you are able to unlock the next rank's missions.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2016
												Mercenary Kings is not Metal Slug. You will not be fighting your way through the level to get from one side of the map to the other. There are no boss fights (that I've come across). You do not pick up weapon drops. You collect materials to take back to your base to unlock new weapon parts. If you think enemies are bullet sponges, then maybe you are using a weak weapon. You do not lose lives until you get game over. Losing all your health will restart you from the continue point, minus first aid costs from the mission reward. You fail the mission if you run out of time, or you spend all the reward on first aid (lives). If you are playing this game with an xbox360 controller then you will have a bad time (no wonder you think the controls are bad). The controls themselves are weird though (says me who can't stand wasd), but you can remap the keyboard to something playable. Mercenary Kings greatest downfall is that it is on pc rather than vita or 3ds.

												Here is my Mercenaray Kings Review in 30Seconds


YouTube™ Video: Mercenary Kings Review in 30 Seconds 

			Views: 1,154		

			You want this game? You can have a key to unlock it. For free. Just confirm your entry and you might win it… Or not. It’s like the lottery, only more attainable. From the good guys at Tribute.		

When you base your game’s aesthetics on Metal Slug, it’s easy to make a good looking game. What’s harder is to give it a twist that makes it a game of it’s own. In Mercenary Kings you craft weapons, armor and mods with loot you pick off of enemies. This is not just for giggles though, the game is hard and you need to craft your own chance at winning.Playing as a team of up to four is a lot of fun, but the scenery is repetitive and even annoying when you are trying to kill a boss and he runs off into another part of the map.Awesome art and funny dialogue in a somewhat monotonous gameplay. But it is still in development, so it has a lot of potential.7 slugs out of 10.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2015
												Mercenary Kings is a style over substance game in my heart. Borrowing heavily on the Metal Slug formula, the gameplay has been updated to current "standards": added replay value, massive crafting system, customization or sidequests just to name a few. If those are not inherently bad, they are not well suited to an arcade-y scrolling shooter.If blasting through ennemy legions is your thing, be prepared to spend most of your time gathering materials by doing the same missions over and over again in order to get better weapons or equipment, some of which are not luxury items or hoarders' prizes but much needed firepower. Completionists will cry tears of blood.I would rather have had a two to three hours fun ride than having to grind my way through the game. If I end up recommending the game it's mostly due to Paul Robertson's amazing pixel art animations and the fact that the game is well designed. There is variety and fun in this game, too bad it's forced down your throat until you're full.

												The only thing good about this game is the art.     Boring repetitive game play traversing the same map over and over for multiple missions killing the same enemies that reappear in the same spots. A crafting system that doesn't give much of an opportunity to experiment or preview weapon builds before spending your resources and too many stats to compare, very little incentive to really use different types of weapons or ammunition when caustic bullets pretty much handle everything. Retrieving items from your backpack is slow and also disrupts game play you should really be able to toggle through items with a single button click rather than having to hold down a button then navigating a menu and then select your item, you also have go through your backpack to get the walkie talkie out just to call someone so you can leave a mission so many clicks for such a simple thing.    I wanted to like this game but I just couldn't get over the frustrating gameplay mechanics. The comparisons to Metal Slug make no sense this is nothing like Metal Slug not even close, If you wanna play a fast pace action platformer play Metal Slug if you want something slow, repetitive, and grindy play this game.

												If you are a fan of having fun, this the game for you. Whether solo or co-op, this game hits on all cylinders and keeps you wanting more and more until its 4 A.M. and you have to go to work in a couple of hours. (Sometimes, they are!) Do yourself a favor, pick up this platforming shooter today, and take the fight to CLAW. They need to be taken down. MOVE OUT!

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												Okay. Now to be honest, I haven't gone through the entire game as yet. But I figure that I've logged in enough game time on it to give some first impressions.Admittedly, what initially drew me to this game was the design itself. It was like Contra meets Scott Pilgrim-- similarly designed sprites, chiptune music and such... so it was something of a guilty pleasure.As a run-and-gun game, there's nothing TOO exceptional about it. The levels are fairly linear, even though there are plenty of nooks and crannies to explore. The story line is okay, though the characters are amusing enough that the plot doesn't plod on.The real challenge lies in trying to master the levels. Not just in the speed-runs, but also with the secret objectives. Things to help you earn the extra scratch and materials to forge new items to not only make the missions more interesting, but to also unlock hidden perks to get through some of the harder missions. Missions are basic in nature, but can vary in difficulty due to time constraints and game AI. And the game AI is basic enough to make taking enemies out both easy and frustrating at the same time. There's also the reload feature, which can boost damage, but requires you to pay enough attention to be a distraction at times.All in all, this is still a fun little run-and-gun, and definitely worth the look when it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												This is a hard one to describe. There are many complaints, but most of those complaints are about people thinking it's going to be similar to Metal Slug, which it's not. It takes inspiration from games like Monster Hunter and Megaman. And the reason I say a game like Monster Hunter is because the crafting system and online missions (Quests) are similar to Monster Hunter's. You have your sub missions and main missions, you must complete all the main missions to unlock your boss mission, or in Monster Hunter your "Urgent Quest," to move on to your next rank or "Hunter Rank."         As for Megaman, the game's enemies and precise shooting mechanics are very similar to the Megaman franchise. So close infact some enemies have the same gameplay mechanics, examples are the Floor Spiders acting the like Springers, and Riot Shields acting like the Sniper Joes from Megaman.         Since Monster Hunter and Megaman are two of my favorite videogame franchises of all time, I love this game, but I understand how some people might go into this game expecting a Metal Slug type game. If that's the case, Metal Slug 3 and X are available on Steam, which I highly recommend as well.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												This is a hard one to describe. There are many complaints, but most of those complaints are about people thinking it's going to be similar to Metal Slug, which it's not. It takes inspiration from games like Monster Hunter and Megaman. And the reason I say a game like Monster Hunter is because the crafting system and online missions (Quests) are similar to Monster Hunter's. You have your sub missions and main missions, you must complete all the main missions to unlock your boss mission, or in Monster Hunter your "Urgent Quest," to move on to your next rank or "Hunter Rank."         As for Megaman, the game's enemies and precise shooting mechanics are very similar to the Megaman franchise. So close infact some enemies have the same gameplay mechanics, examples are the Floor Spiders acting the like Springers, and Riot Shields acting like the Sniper Joes from Megaman.         Since Monster Hunter and Megaman are two of my favorite videogame franchises of all time, I love this game, but I understand how some people might go into this game expecting a Metal Slug type game. If that's the case, Metal Slug 3 and X are available on Steam, which I highly recommend as well.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												Mercenary Kings or the revival of a long forgotten genre!To make a long storry short Mercenray Kings is what i expect from a good 2D-Platformer. A good Gameplay, a decent storry and a good Soundtrack (even if it sounds like  16bit).First things first: If you want a High-End 3D-Shoother you´re ABSOLUTELY not looking for this game. BUT: If you enjoy playing 2-D Platformers (like the famous Megaman games or the early Castlevania games on the NES or SNES)  you´ll definitely have a lot of fun with Mercenary Kings.The graphics look a little like the games back in the good old times of the SNES. But thanks since these times have passed its looks are more smooth and less edgy. The designers put a lot of time and thought into creating the levels and models.  8/10The storry itself has no big twists  and unforseen turns but the Characters are designed with a lot of love. 8/10The gameplay is simple and easy to learn (what´s not so surpising since we talk about a Platformer^^)A nice idea that sure keeps you going is the almost infinite gunsmithing possibilities. Every part you equip can change how you move and shoot. It takes about 15-20 hours to beat the game (15 if you rush through the game, 20 if you take care of all the small sidequest that alsmot every mission has). 10/10The soundtrack is as retro as the looks of this game and therefor a perfect match. No fancy orchestral sound, no incredible guitarr riffs but still an enjoyable and throughout the whole game well matched music. 7/10One of the greates features of this game is the co-op mode where up to 4 players can join the fight. It never gets old to play a game like that with your friends ;)Overall Rating, 8.5/10

												Alright, so this is colored two ways. One side is from me and one is from a 4 year old kid.Me, I think this game is brilliant. I love that there's no forced screen share. I can go do my own thing while my team mate secures other objectives. The art is amazing and the story is interesting and fun. The crafting system brings a new depth to this sort of console side scroller and I appreciate that. Being able to choose missions is great. Not a huge fan of my partner dying x number of times and mission failed. I was a glob darm rock star. I also played this split screen on a 36" HD monitor and thought it was a little too little....a single group map would be fine or no map below would be even better.....I play 10 days on Don't Starve before I start thinking "maybe I need a map..."Kid thinks it's crazy fun too. His big complaint is "these bad guys keep beating me, are you kidding me?" I personally like the challange but he'd like a throw back to the time when a screen is shared and the hardcore gamer in the group blasts the faces and he passes out the heals (he's a good TF2 medic and a good collector of crafting items....he also got me out of a few hairy situations where I was reloading and thinking I was about to die). He likes Metal Slug more.Overall a very positive experience and I look forward to playing more. So does he, he cried his eyes out when I told him it was time to stop playing and go home. Great game, hope there's some cheap DLC or a modders tool-kit around the corner.Hap Hollys

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Worth the money, but its squeezing every drop from it's maps almost to the point of boredom.There are 10 ranks (Chapters) with around 11 missions each.  I am on Chapter 3, but have only seen 5 stages.  The data files have 10 stage BGMs suggesting limited locations.  Missions are repeatable and are very forgiving if failed (you keep what you collected).  You also pick up loot drops for weapon and item crafting. These features combined with the "Hub" between missions gives the game a co-op MMO feel.   Less Contra, More Borderlands.  Not at all bad, but if you are not expecting that, the game feels slowly paced.  Also be aware that weapon crafting feels like a crap shoot at first, as you can make underperforming combinations of parts.   Expect to make a bunch of parts and then experiment.  Tried to make a rifle and thought I wasted my money, turns out I didnt have a matched barrel and magazine to make it shine.Overall, I expected something closer to the arcade style Metal Slug, but this game is really, really fun.  It also has some fantastic chiptunes.  I have not tried Multiplayer yet.  Waiting until I can get a bettter Internet connection.
