content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
It seems odd to me that people didn't get what Mercenary Kings was before it was released. When I watched the gameplay footage, it was very clear that the game features mechanics as Monster Hunter such as collecting materials for crafting (a LOT of it), 3 lives per mission in total (especially important in multiplayer), and timed missions. Unlike Metal Slug, which is a really fast paced 2D game, MK is more tactical, forcing you to think your approach on enemies, or die and respawn at the start point of the mission (kind like Castlevania). This creates tension, and challenge. I don't understand why people complain about not being able to shoot in a diagonal direction, as you couldn't do it in Metal Slug either, but okay.  Gameplay variations come in bionic mods, which consist on equipping up to two ability enchaning mods, along with their respective penalties; then, there is the really extensive weapon crafting in both guns and blades. This is pretty much the core mechanic of the game. Gun parts will change your damage, ammo, firing speed, weight, element, bullet compatibility, etc. Properties for knives such as range, speed, element, and others also apply. Craft enough parts of the same weapon type, and you get proficiencies, which work as an additional mod, but with no penalties. If you have played Monster Hunter, Valdis Story or any other game which focuses a lot on defeating enemies to finally get the item you need, it's worth the time, because a new kind of weapon completely changes the way you approach enemies. Mission types go from eleminating enemies in a certain area, to rescue missions, hunting missions, capture missions, material finding, etc. etc. Yes, you may feel that you have to replay maps a lot, but factors such as time, starting points, and even enemies will change as you progress through the game. Backtracking and respawing enemies work in a way that you have to very careful about not wandering mindlessly and be on your toes, as enemies will be there again, but you will encounter them from another angle, making you think twice about how to kill them once again. This also works in your favor for material collecting purposes. The fleeing Boss mechanic, I felt, works as a time and ability challenge. It can work for or against you. The thing about Bosses escaping, is that you can open the map, and you will see the skull icons where the boss actually is, so it's about how fast you can get there and finish the job. Multiplayer is a blast, as you and your friends can tackle the missions from different points. You are not bound all together in the same screen, but can work individually when it comes to finding enemies or items in order to complete the mission. Also, if you pick up a material, all your friends will get it too, so it makes crafting a lot faster. If you hated going against a Boss solo, a multiplayer session will allow you and your friends to completely wreck those Steel Soldiers, Mechanic Hounds and many others. One thing of caution, though. I said that you have 3 lives in total per mission, not per player. So watch out for trigger happy companions, or loners, because if they day very far away from any support, "Mission Failed" is a highly likely scenario, so teamwork is never out of the question, and THAT'S the beauty of it. There are adrenaline shots to revive your comrades or yourself in these situations, but mind the inventory limit, as choices must be made, so once again, tactics is the word of the day.  There is also the platformer aspect of the game, so be careful about how hard you press the jump button. So, not only will you fight CLAW, but you will find the stages themselves. The reload mechanic is something you must master, as you must always be aware of how much ammo you got left before reloading. By reloading, you will see a black, yellow and green bar above you. If you time well your reloading and hit the green section of the bar, you will get a bonus damage for the amount of bullets your reloaded. If you miss, you'll be unable to shoot for a period of time, defined by the load time of the weapon you're carrying (So you better have a nicely forged knife to compensate). This mechanic adds even more tension to the game, because you won't always be standing still as you watch your reload bar, but you may be in a heated Boss battle, or sorrounded by enemies, so mastering your reload time for every weapon you carry is a must. For the enemy part of the game, there is a nice variety of them. Not to mention that some enemies will level up in a way, and be stronger and change their attack patterns. The same goes for Bosses, and you will encounter some powered-up ones, which likely make your day harder (if you have played Monster Hunter, this if quite familiar). If you get into trouble at missions, you can always rest at the infirmary, which works both as a healing station (kind slow, so watch your times) and a spawn point, so if you die, you will respawn at the last infirmary you entered. As I see it, people who really didn't like this game (and played for about 15 minutes of it), were expecting a super-fast paced shooting game, like metal slug. This is more tactical, as I said, like Castlevania, Metroid, Monster Hunter, etc. You can't be shooting endlessly or moving really fast with a full pleged machine gun in  your arms. Other were expecting things to be really casual and easy, but Mercenary Kings isn't that kind of game. If you can stand a challenge, and master the speed and mechanics of this game, satisfaction is a feeling that will get to you eventually. Also, after end-game, you can keep playing in order craft every weapon part there is, or just try the different kind of bullets and guns, just to see how you fare with them. Are you a revolver or hand-gun kind of person? Maybe shotguns are your thing. Maybe a Sniper Rifle, or a Machine gun. Maybe you like it close and personal, and your knife gets the best out of you. Changing a weapon type is pretty much changing your experiencie in the game, so give it a shot. Design and artstyle-wise, the game is beautiful. If you like pixel art, the character designs are stylish, both friends and enemies. The game plays really smooth, and the map details are very well done. I'm not picky with graphics in videogames, so for me this really easy on the eyes. When it comes to controls, I'm the rare kind of player who prefers the keyboard. The default keys are what I use, and at first they're kind of weird, but using your right hand as a second WASD actually makes sense in this game (at least for me). The thing to watch out for are the roll and the knife controls. If you don't want to trouble yourself with the roll button, you can enable the double-tap option to get that out of your way. Now you deal only with shoot, knife and jump. Of course, there is the reload button and how you handle your inventory, but all it takes is a button configuration or a controller set-up to better suit your needs. Anyway, that's my way of covering how this game does what it does. I can see that it's not for the VERY casual players, or those who expect really fast paced 2D shooters (which I also love), but I wouldn't call it hardcore either. It's about letting Mercenary Kings grow on you if the general idea doesn't fully convince you yet, but I can't blame you if this isn't really the game for you. Just don't go with the "It's hard because I'm not super powerful" kind of reviews. This is a game that rewards your intelligence and your ability more than it rewards your farming for materials in order to craft the best equipment. I hope this helps you out in that decisive "Yes or No" for this game in particular, and keep on playing.

Posted: September 7, 2015
												summary of this game:a half baked attempt to recreate the wonders that where contra and metal slug. cute and well animated visuals won't save this stiff and harsh (and very tedious) try hard.with every mission you go on, you have a stupid timer, with no real indicators as to where you have to go to find what you have to find (i only did 2 missions and gave up after a ton of stupid deaths).the controls are fidgety and there is no diagonal shooting, which doesnt make sense b/c the game it is trying to pay hommage to had diagonal shooting (as well as super tight controls).the one decent, though at the same time frustraing (and kind of stupid) concept is the weapon crafting system. you can customise every part of your guns... this would be fun and cool, but the resources are random drops from enemies and crates and you have to go over each item and 'duck' to pick it up, which sometimes puts you in harms way (dont forget that you have a timer as well and cant afford to die and/or do loot hunting).there is also a death penatly (cash loss) and you have to restart from either the beginning, or a random tent you find lying around, which doesnt make things any more fun imo.sound and visuals are decent, though nothing to write home about.this game was on my radar for a while b/c it looked like a faithful adaptation of a childhood favourite of mine (metal slug 3) but alas, it is just a half baked wanna be that has since been abandoned (it was hyped up so much before official release and crowd funding and now the team has disappeared).save your money or buy it when it goes dirt cheap (less then 50% standard retail would be good).

												You may seen this intro a lot in the review: I really wanted to like this game. Pixelated but colorful art, old school with a modern touch, etc... that's all truth and likeable. But I really had a problem with the gameplay, something that should be a star in this kind of games. First, this does not play like Metal Slug in an aspect. May look like it, but is more like a cheap megaman knockoff. Yep, I'm this harsh because the scenarios and platforming is filled with lame and boring challenges, timed repetitive missions and enemies that are just not fun to fight.Weapon crafting is still pretty good, and it may intrigue you what you can build with what you find, but honestly, this is the reason I usually don't dig in this kind of mechanic: I have to wade trough repetitive gameplay until it's grating. I might be compensated with building great guns and upgrades, but with such lame enemies to fight, what's the point? It's like playing XBlades in a Turrican-Megaman uninspired perspective.If you want to play Metal Slug, it's here on steam. If you want to meet the untalented son of Diablo and Megaman, get this.

Posted: June 15, 2016
												Merc Kings has a great art style as you can see and that can go a long way if you like it. I find it to be fun despite a little repeatativeness. You find yourself going to the same areas several times on different missions. I understand it adds some replay value but it can feel redundant. The gameplay, in general, is fun. Obviously there's numberous weapon upgrades and combinations, it's really interesting to mess around and tweak with those. What a lot of reviewers don't mention is that there are other mods like armor, health, melee knife, and bullet mods. You collect material found on missions for all these upgrades. I didn't find myself struggling too much to save up for the mods I wanted. Yes there's fetch missions but they are purely optional and usually offer big material bonuses.Pros-Fun quirky graphic/art style-co-op online and local-upgrades!-full controller support-moderate difficultyCons-several missions repeat map areas -fetch missions-zomg its not metal slug!! 												This platformer's level design very much reminds me of Mega Man.You play as a mercenary, doing missions for some army dude. The missions are: find this, kill that, rescue someone. You advance through the ranks by completing story missions. Every time you advance you get new gun parts in the store. You craft them by obtaining materials and money in missions.The gun crafting system is interesting, you can combine parts from guns with other parts from other guns. The sniper rifles are way overpowered. Their range is insane, you always shoot with 100% accuracy and your bullets will pierce infinitely throught walls and enemies alike.I did not pay much attention to the story. For me this game is about running around shooting at stuff and building the best gun.tl/drFun game for co-op or single player with lots of pew pew!

Product received for free
												The game has its flaws, but no game is without such things. To give a game grief for not being flawless is setting a standard bar well beyond realistic expectations and there for being unreasonable. Also most of the negative reviews have hardly clocked enough time to really get into the game.The short:This is a great time killer and if you like making prospect of making tons of whacky weapon combos and personal perks to enhance your character's speed, jump and other stuff then you'll love this game even if there are some spelling errors in text and the occasional bug.The long:This game is not a Metal Slug clone, it takes a lot of inspiration from it like character designs, setting, some minor game mechanics and combat from Metal Slug but its not a fast paced side scrolling shooter. The game actually reminds me more of the old Castlevenia games withwith its multi layered levels and hidden areas. This is not a game where you'll forever be blasting your way forward (like how Metal Slug games play) without turning back, you will need to take time to farm for materials to build better weapons and perks. The repetiveness of farming can be troublesome for players who just want to rush on ahead but for players who actually enjoy all the benefits of being able to craft more weapon parts it pays off in spades (90+ hours and I still haven't made everything or done all the side missions).This coop in this game is also really fun, my advice is wait till its on sale and buy the 4 pack for yourself and 3 pals.In fact as much as i love this game I don't think its worth almost 20USD, its a time sink sure but thats mainly if you want to make and try out new weapon sets and combinations (the farming can really eat up time). So do I highly recommend this game but not at full price and only if you can handle grinding for crafting fun stuff.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Mercenary Kings is a cynical college art project masquerading as a videogame. In less than an hour of playtime, the game managed to show every possible hint of amatuerism in its design. A design based on games from decades ago that had better control schemes.The biggest flaw with this "game" is the incredibly poor design decisions. The first mistake was the addition of reload for what should have been a relatively simple run-and-gun experience. It breaks the flow of gameplay and often just leaves you huddling behind some barrels until you've reloaded. Not that taking cover matters; The enemies barely move and the barrels are always taller than you are, so you have to jump into enemy fire anyway. This is compounded by absolutely byzantine level design that makes backtracking endless and goals impossible. It doesn't help that enemies respawn faster than this game being pushed out the door. On top of that, the game often imposes time limits on your escapades. The result is endlessly frustrating. The "developers" clearly haven't taken much notice in the games they were so intent on emulating: You can't shoot diagonally. Even Contra, a game released in the late '80s, allowed the player to shoot diagonally. There's no reason this could not have been done here.Mercenary Kings is so bad I thought it was an Early Access title because it has no features and is overpriced. It looks like someone took a game with one level and no interesting game mechanics, gave it a nice art style and called it a day. Normally, I would cut the devs some slack, seeing as it's a Kickstarter and probably their first game, but the pricetag is just insulting for the amount of content (that I've read about; Apparently there's a useless crafting system). Only a Kickstarter could raise $100,000 for a game to be $20 and have the same content as a gif of the opening and closing animated sequences. The lack of gameplay coherence and common sense gives me the sneaking suspision that the game was mostly an ego trip for an art student.I don't recommend this game at full price. I don't recommend this game on sale. I actually got it on Humble Bundle for a dollar and I still can't recommend it. No, wait, my brother paid for that bundle, so I got it for free. No, wait, my brother owes me twenty bucks. I got paid to play this game and I still can't recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												I can recommend this game, because I've been having a fairly good time with the basic gameplay... BUT.... a concession to the cautious buyer: the longer you play, the initial fun level begins to diminish as you begin to notice how the game extensively recycles assets and mission types. Mercenary Kings is perfectly content to repeatedly send you off on the same 3 types of fetch quests in one of the same 3 maps, over and over, again and again, for hours.Mercenary Kings is the equivalent of that FPS you play that isn't really outstanding, but also isn't bad, and turns out to be a really great way to just kill a half an hour. It's a game you can hop into quickly, and missions can take anywhere between 5 minutes up to 30 minutes. If you're just looking to kill some time shooting a couple dudes while looking at some great pixel art, then Mercenary Kings fits the bill marvelously.If you're a fan of old school side-scrolling shooters (e.g. Metroid, Contra, Gunstar Heroes, Cave Story), etc, then you're probably going to enjoy this game well enough to make it worth the purchase (especially at a sale price). There is **EVENTUALLY** (very, very eventually) a variety of ammo types, and it can be interesting discovering how different ammo types can have unique effects on certain types of enemies (e.g. when you shoot an enemy hiding behind a riot shield with caustic ammo, the riot shield melts away and changes the enemy's behavior).However, I specifically say AMMO types and not GUN types for good reason. One of the most loudly advertised aspects of the game---and definitely one of the most attractive---is the ability to pick up various "materials" dropped by enemies, which you can then sell for money or use at crafting stations to create new parts for your gun or various other perks. The game is very proud of these mildly RPG-esque and clearly Borderlands-derived elements, but the implementation is hit or miss. The ammo types are implemented pretty well. The gun parts... meh.After dumping over 10 hours into the game (and having a fairly good time, mind you), and experimenting with different gun mods, my honest opinion is that the vast majority of craftable gun parts and passive skills are more or less pointless. The game undermines upgrades and customizations in the vast majority of cases by giving an upgrade with one hand while stealing it back with the other.For example, suppose you currently have a clip size of 8 and a damage rating of 150, and you want to upgrade your clip size to fire more shots before stopping to reload. The game might let you upgrade your clip size to 12, but it knocks your damage down to 100 and slows your walking speed. Suppose you decide to skip the clip size upgrade then and just upgrade raw damage? The game might let you boost raw damage to 200, but it will reduce your clip size to 4 shots and slow your walking speed. Or it might alternatively lett you have the 200 raw damage while reducing your magazine size to 7, but the cost is your reload speed is now three times as slow. In short, most of the unlockable weapon parts aren't so much "upgrades" as much as they are like sliders that you can use to change CHARACTERISTICS of your weapon, but which don't really IMPROVE your weapon overall.Also, you CAN'T SHOOT DIAGONALLY in this game. Which is annoying, because enemies CAN shoot diagonally, and flying enemies will attack you from a diagonal direction. This is a terrible oversight. It might have been fine if being attacked from a diagonal angle wasn't such a problem, but the game makes you wish for that diagonal aim through enemy behavior suggesting that you should have it, and then for some reason, you don't. When I noticed that, I shook my head and I said hm. Just hm. Tsk tsk. What a shame.That being said, once you get several hours in and get up to about the third rank, you start acquiring weapon parts that make your gun compatible with elemental ammo. Therein lie the REAL upgrades. You can even get up to a point where you can have an elemental version of a specific bullet type. For example, you can create a gun that shoots bullets that are both CAUSTIC and also PIERCING. Caustic bullets burn away at enemies (and sometimes melt away their defenses) while piercing bullets can travel through walls and objects to hit unsuspecting enemies on the other side. Piercing bullets can also travel through several enemies in a line. And, of course, the damage is better. Now THESE are upgrades.In short, the various weapon parts don't add a whole lot outside of letting you use custom ammo. The custom ammo is the real game changer.There are other craft stations not related to weapon crafting, but these also don't offer anything that significantly improves your character or game experience. Some of them are terribly pointless. One of the better examples is the ability to craf better armor, which provides a definite and noticeable boost to the amount of damage you can sustain. The craftable passive skills, on the other hand, aren't particularly interesting. They COULD be, but are implemented poorly. For example, there is a passive skill that brags it can burst your speed, but at the cost of some of your physical defense. Again with the giving with one hand while taking with the other. If the benefits made the trade-off worthwhile, then it might not be so bad, but the "speed boost" you receive is so slight that I found myself turning it off and on again to test whether it was actually working. Not exactly the sort of "speed boost" I would sacrifice defense for.Some of the crafting options I even find downright ridiculous. For example, you can give a bunch of your materials and some money to the chef who will craft a meal for you, which gives you a perk in the next mission only. But the perks are laughably negligible. Things like a 5% increase to maximum health. Five percent? This kind of thing could just as well not exist and I wouldn't even miss it or notice it was gone.Honestly, I played all the way up through Corporal rank using the STARTING weapon. No mods offer significant enough changes to be worthwhile up until that point. I bought a lot of the upgrades to advance toward some of those skills that unlock with a certain number of purchases, but I didn't equip any of them. Didn't see the point.The game's hugest and most serious problem, however, is recycling. I have played the game for 10 hours and completed nearly 50 missions. All of these missions have taken place in the same 3 levels. I am very sick of the jungle.On the plus side, the boss battles are pretty fun (but also recycled).TLDR: Mercenary Kings  isn't going to win any awards, and it recycles too much, and its weapon customization is mostly talk, but if you just want to spend a few minutes shooting some 2-dimensional dudes while looking at some great pixel art, then Mercenary Kings is a great game to kill time with.

content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												So, first off - the game is beautiful, the animation is fluid and funny, the game has a ton of character, it's a Scott Pilgrim nod to Metal Slug.  All those things are great... but the gameplay.  EVERY mission is a timed variation on a fetch quest, and most of the environments look the exact same.  Timed missions ALONE would dissuade me from continuing, but I kept at it because I really wanted to like it.  I figured weapon customization would save the game, but alas, unless you make very specific weapons, they tend to be pretty worthless.  I was hoping for a Loadout-esque customization system, but the game really just wants you to buy parts to make a shotgun.  Or a sniper rifle.  If you get creative in any way, the negatives are so huge that it's not worth the effort - I went from a standard magazine weapon with 6 shots to a larger magazine, and my damage dropped about 80% - so though I had more bullets to a clip, I was doing far LESS damage with each shot.  If you can handle mazey fetch quests, give it a shot.  It's a solid backbone, it has a lot of things going for it, but it just felt too clunky and grindey to me.  Such a shame, I'd been looking forward to playing it for a while now.

Posted: December 29, 2014
												Don't let the negative reviews fool you. Yes it isn't Metal Slug, but just because it looks like it, it shouldnt play like it. This a Metal Slug style with a Monster Hunter vibe to it. The ability to customize your gun into any shape or form is the drive to this game. Now unless you wanna unlock every gun part, yes it WILL be a grind, but if you know what you want, you'll blaze through this game. By want I mean, you know what kind of gun you'll want to make. Spread patterns are all the same (this aint Counter Strike son), so a gun with 90% Acc will be the same across all fields, is just the ammunition that affects the pattern (Buckshots will not follow the same predetermined path as a Magnum Bullet). The only downfall this game has is there is no seamless map, you'll have to do different missions to go to the different maps. You will be doing the same maps over and over a couple of times, but you will be doing different parts of it to complete objectives. This can be a good or bad thing, as the missions are planned out so you know where to go for the main boss of the area (As bosses can/will run away to different parts of the map, and will need to know how to get there from previous playings). I find this game enjoyable, as others not so much, and for vain reasons.PROS-Customized Weapons-Variety of Parts-4 Player Co-Op (Both Online and Local)[Unknown if it can be mixed]-Great Boss Battles-Rainbow Dog of Doom that craps rockets at you-Large Maps-Shared Items in Co-Op mode (When finding, not crafting)-Tougher Enemies in Co-Op modeCONS-Low Replayablity-2 Characters-Enemy Variety is low (In the beginning)-Farm to Unlock all Parts-Few Maps-You will hate Rainbow Dog of DoomPretty even list of Pros and Cons, but my experience with the game as been fun, and I have been playing Solo. I think the Pros outweigh the Con in my experiences, this not a game for everyone. If you want a Metal Slug game, then buy, its there in the store, just do it. If you want a nice Side-scrolling, Action Platformer, with Customizable Weapons, I would get this.

												DO NOT BUY IT! UNTIL YOU READ!! SERIOUSLY!!!If you are expecting this game to be like Metal Slug, Metal Assault, or Contra. Turn away right now. The game is better with Controler (HIGHLY RECOMENDED) With Keyboard, it is hellish to play.So this game seem to have something new to it's style, unlike METAL SLUG. This game offers Crafting weapons, buying items, character customization and varrious mission to play. Not to mention online co-op for friends to join. SO WHAT WENT WRONG?!Level Design choicesUNLIKE METAL SLUG, this game is a CHORE! Most of the mission is  fetch quest style mission. The first mission was finding ONE hostage. (seems okay) Then the game do the exact same thing for second mission WITH 8 HOSTAGES! By the way, it's on the same map. (OR it look very similar, which make the game feels repetitive)YOU DON'T FEEL LIKE A BADASS! This game is more difficult than Metal Slug, GOOD! However..., the game refuses to throw any retaliation! (I'm going to compare this to Metal Slug again.) In Metal Slug, you will encounter TANKS, 10+ Footsoilders, HELICOPTERs, and so on. This make the game fun, and give that satisfying feeling of destorying everything like any RUN n GUN game should be. But all you'll encounter in this game is just repetitive respwanable enemies. For example, sending 3 melee soldiers and die by 1 SINGLE BULLET. Or having 1 or 2 riflemen attacking you. Compare that to Metal Slug or Contra. SLOW EVERYTHING IS SLOW. The fact that this game force you to do search n destory, or fetching an objective. Forces you to wonder around the map trying to find that LAST GUY WHO YOU MENT TO KILL. Again, unlike Contra or Metal Slug, this game doesn't proceed quickly. Infact, it probably force you to GRIND. That's right, having a crafting system is good, but you need to grind for the materials. I don't want to do that, this is not an MMORPG. The game does give you in-game money allowing you buy items. BUT NOT MATERIALS. NOPE YOU GOTTA GRIND FOR IT. May I ask why!? Combat MechanicHonestly, very disappointed. I'll make this short. Why is there a reload mini game? Does it have any purpose? It was more like a punishment rather than FUN. I mean, reloading itself is already difficult. Or maybe it's not difficult in this game? BECAUSE THE GAME HARDLY throw enemies at you! While it adds abit of challenge during boss fight, I find it more... annoying. There's no real reward for hitting the right time for reload minigame, but only punishment when you hit too early or too late. I rather just hit reload and just wait. Other than that the mini game mechanic, is a waste of space.Final things I would like to add.WHY DO I ONLY HAVE A PISTOL!? Where's my nade? WHY IS THERE A TIMER!? WHY DOES IT COST MONEY TO DIE?! Isn't losing one life not enough!? For PC, IF YOU HAVE NO CONTROLER! DO NOT BUY!! Was expecting something like Metal Assault, which was an MMO but have a very good mechanic, you can use your mouse to aim, and shoot with LF-Click. SIMPLE!? Why didnt the developer think of this?!?! Buy, at your own risk. Good Day.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Fun for a few hours of "retro fix", but ultimately, like many of the game it emulates, this game lacks the thrill of a responsive, empowering and progressive platformer.  It's not the sort of Borderlands-meets-MegamanX that I was imagining.The Merc characters feel clumsey and sluggish.  The guns (so far) are very limited ( "shotgun type parts" or "machine gun type parts").  It's common to sink missions-worth-of-earnings into building a worse gun.  There are no items or abilities aside that make you feel awesome, give any strategy or variety.  You're (so far) just a dopey run/jump/duck/shoot/roll character, fighting the same 10 enemies with predictable patterns and no real reason (i.e. relevant loot or an xp system) to grind through.Enemies feel like they're just in the way of the objective, fighting through the same stage over and over to complete their many missions.  A lot of time is spent hoping that the effort it will take to, yet again, trek through the same grid of caves, cliffs and structures, will be worth a few lines of character dialogue and the assumption that all the stuff you've been picking up will be useful some day.The story, characters and artwork are all very pleasant, but the game mechanics/design makes most of the game a chore to slog through, unfortunately.  No randomized content.  One stage of the same stuff for hours.  Beyond that, I can only guess the formula repeats itself.Perhaps after only a few more hours, something along the lines of interesting/useful weapon options, character abilities (wall jump?  double jump?  wall slide?  crawl?  lock on/aim? Grenades? ect.), more stages, or anything else that feels like a reward will emerge.  Until then, it's just chasing repeat bosses that move before you even get to them for hours, and grinding through armies of annoying bad guys for obscure matterials.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
												First, I'll start by addressing the cons many people mention. This game does revisit the same areas. What it does right about this mechanic is that it will often lock certain areas of that map until you clear specific missions, and the variety of the missions more than make up for this.The crafting and customization that a person can use to suit their playstyle is varied enough to suit anyone's taste. Homing guns, projectiles that explode with shrapnel on impact, piercing rounds, elemental rounds, and even player buffs that can make a melee build one of the most lethal.The multiplayer co-op is the most fun feature of this game. Whether local or online, the players are free to explore separate areas of the same map, versus locking you in the same screen (as does Metal Slug, a game that cleraly inspired this one). The only negative part that players may find is that local co-op is split screen, so plan to be close to the screen if it is not a large one. Also, players can leave whenever they feel like it (even the host) without forcing other players to quit, and players can join at any point in between missions.The most impressive ascpect of this game is the commitment that the developers have to ensuring that it is a great game. Their persistence in ironing out bugs is rare for an indie team. This is reason enough to buy the game, and to buy future titles from this team.Graphics are one of the last thing I care about so long as the game works, and it does. On that note, the art style in this game is fantastic.TL;DR: Lots of crafting and player build customization, varied missions, drop in/drop out co-op campaign, great art style/graphics, dedicated developer team.9/10

												Disclaimer: I might not "get" the game.This game is hard to love, it's one of those games that has the promise of combining all the best parts of old skool games. I'm sure at some level this was what the developers are going for, a nostalgic game they would've liked to see, indisriminately taking the things we all loved about platformers etc.Sadly, it's more like the best and the absolute worst aspects of games from the 8bit and 16bit era. It's as if the developers have learned absolutely nothing from modern game design. This game is extremely frustrating, and most of it comes down to horrible design and core mechanics. The biggest issue I have apart from the bad overall design, is that while the developers have tried to combine many different elements from successful games, the overall experience is worse off than any of those individual games it tries to imitate.Some gameplay choices don't play well with each other and their attempt at syncretizing these becomes detrimental to the overall experience,I tried playing this game with multiple friends, and it's hard for me to insist on it when it's obvious no one is enjoying a single second of it.A real shame, but the era for frustrating pieces of♥♥♥♥♥♥that you just love to hate are over.However, if you're one of those people that is scourging through the reviews to find reassuring confirmation of why you'd love this game, and are desperate for the possible potential it might have I would in fact recommend this game. You might not play it for very long, but it does have an allure of enjoyment, one that it doesn't really deliver on, but afterall, like the developers, sometimes we like the idea of something over the actual thing itself.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												Metal Slug meets Monster Hunter? Oh hell yeah!If you're a Monster Hunter passionate, such as myself, you will definitely LOVE  this title. The feeling you get is very close, and a lot of mechanics are present in both games: Weapons can be forged, and they come in various shapes and colors. Not only that, but weapon parts are divided in categories which alter the way they work. The main area is a small village, where all the NPCs live. Many of them also resemble ones from Capcom's franchise: the general who gives you missions, the cook who... erm, cooks you food (which gives fixed AND chance-based bonuses), the gunsmith who forges all your gun parts from monster materials, and so many others.  Areas work similarly to how they do in Monster Hunter, being divided in zones and having enemies indigenous to them. However, in this game most enemies tend to respawn as soon as they leave your field of view. Oh, and I didn't talk about boss fights yet! Bosses can be killed OR captured, and overall the pattern-learning process behind defeating them for the first time feels the same.Then comes CoOp. You can play together with up to four people, and you all share the same lives. There's a built-in voice-command system, too. I could go on, but I hope you get the point.If, however, you're considering buying Mercenary Kings for the Metal Slug part, you'll be slightly disappointed: while it mantains all the glorious 2D shootin' goodness, it lacks a bit of the fast-paced and action-packed gameplay that makes Metal Slug what it's well known for. Also, there are no power-ups scattered around the map or dropped by your foes, for instance.Overall? I don't even know where to begin: some great but not overly complex pixel-art, an amazing soundtrack, interesting characters, an addicting gameplay and the CoOp mode are all important points that give a strong first impression. Maybe it's not really worth €20, but you should totally get it if it drops below €15.

content:
Posted: February 6
The Short Of It" If I want to torment myself and grind for levels & mats, I'm going to play an MMO or an RPG.Note: This game is NOT an MMO nor an RPG.The Long Of It: Oh, where to begin...Oddly enough, this game has something of a story; namely, some evil organization plans on causing a big ol' ruckus (in this case, eternal plant-based warfare). Fair enough. Not much to speak of, but there have been dumber plots.Once you get into the game, expect to grind, grind, grind. You grind for mats to make better gun parts. You'll grind missions for money and mats. You have to grind crafting to make parts and unlock proficiencies (I guess it was just too easy to kill stuff to unlock bonuses, wasn't it, game?), which will make you better at grinding missions for money and parts. Its a big ol' circle of grindiness. Combat is a right♥♥♥♥♥♥as well. There's only four directions to aim in (while some enemies have eight >:| ), and you can't aim down unless you're jumping because holding down while standing makes you go prone. Additionally, some enemies have far too much health. Nevermind the poor placement and dumb-as-rocks AI. I can't tell you how many times that ♥♥♥♥♥ in the drill tank thing ran me over before I managed to kill one of them. Oh, and enemies respawn the INSTANT you leave the screen, so expect to get stabbed, bitten, and shot multiple times passing through the same area!I'm not going to claim that I am the best at these kinds of games, but it really feels like this one just wants me to stop playing it...Honestly, some of this game feels over-engineered. The crafting system is unnecessary -- just let me buy my parts and guns, dammit! -- and the respawning enemies are especially galling unless you have the map memorized. As stated previously, if I wanted to grind, I'll go play an MMO or an RPG, not an action shooty platformer.I do want to love this game. It has a great aestetic and seems like it could be fun, but there's just so much that feels off for being a finalized product. If you really must have your Metal Slug, then go play Metal Slug (or maybe Broforce). If you really feel like grinding something, play an oldie RPG. Just don't play this game. :(

The only thing this game does new is blend RPG progression with a slow and stiff side scrolling shooter, and it doesn't even do that well.

												Many of you are probably leery (as I was) about dropping 20 bucks on this game. I hope that this review will help you make your decision. The game is certainly not for everyone, but I will go into it's pros and cons shortly.First, I would like to adress many of the complaints I have seen in other reviews. Many seem to think that the controls are clunky. This is true- at first. after 30 minutes or so of gameplay, the controls seemed natural to me. If they really bother you, you can always remap them quite easily. I also read many reviews which stated that the jumping seemed unresponsive. The only time I have noticed this is when I have attempted to jumo when in a prone position (laying down). Otherwise, the jumping mechanic seems just fine to me. Some also complain about the reusing of maps. I can certainly see why some people may become irritated by this, but it doesn't bother me. Since you're always completing a different mission, the maps do not seem too repetitive. Let me just say that Mercenary Kings is a fantastic game that deserves a lot more attention than it is currently getting. The retro-style gameplay combined with the endless weapon customization makes for one of the most enjoyable gameplay experiences I've had. The character animations are worthy of an award, and the maps and backgrounds look fantastic. I'm not too far into the campaign, but so far it has been fantastic. At first, it may seem overly difficult, but if you just do some part swapping with your gun, you should be fine. I will update this review with some of my favorite beginner weapon setups soon.The only thing I have found irritating about this game is the lack of a chat menu in multiplayer games. This is extremely minor, however, and will most likely be fixed in a later update. Overall, I would highly reccomend this game to anyone looking for a great retro-style gaming experience. It's well worth the $20. I hope this review was helpful to all of you ladies and mentlegen. 13/10Let's kick some CLAW!

												A reboot of those old-school action packed platformers. But with RPG elements, like crafting your own prefered equipment. Sounds good right? Well this game is not very good. It is boring.The problem is threefold:- you now need to "grind" materials for upgrades. And then you need to build a bunch of random stuff to unlock proficiencies. I got bored with this system and the available options about 10 missions in. Surely late game stuff might be nice and all, it is an unattractive system early on. Especially because you have no idea where you should be farming in the first place.- the maps are the same, over and over again. Same enemies, but that is not all, they are applied in a very repetetive way as well. Sniper on a ledge where you need to get close, rifleman jumping down on you, spearmen attacking from above, drill in a hole, metal drone when you zipline down. Repeat 20 times every stage. There, spoiled the first 3 maps, on which you do at least 3-5 missions each. Boring and annoying.- the "quests" you get to do are boring. Gather 10 of this. (random drops or in boxes, so walk around the entire map. Again) Go to this NPC. And even the Boss, which could have been interesting, is annoying and boring. He moves from the scene at random. So you have to go through the level you got to know by heart by now, AGAIN to find he moves away after just one attack, so you have to track him down AGAIN.Oh and it gets worse: Then you get to do that boss AGAIN. Same map, same fight, but now you have to finish with a shock grenade. Which is the first time you get to use these, they are hard to use, you get only three, so then if you fail to get it right 3 times, you can just as well go and restart the map. After two runs so facing and beating this boss 3 times I had enough.No more waiting in an infirmary for 50 seconds (!?!) to heal up, no more cleaning up / skipping the same enemies 20 times over and finding that you have 50/9 for one craftin component and 1/2 out of some random rare drop you never can seem to find.3/10, would not be bored by again.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Crafting is one of the worst plagues upon modern gaming, and here is one of its worst itinerations.  The missions often take place in the same few maps, merely putting the start and finish lines in different areas.  The reload mechanic is completely out of place in a game like this.  Boss fights are the worst because said bosses will randomly leave the area and require you to track them down anew.  The music is a confused mess, unsure of whether it wants to go full chiptune or not.  The overall goal is also muddled; the game rewards you for speedrunning missions, and also for taking time to explore and fulfill extra objectives, leaving players wondering if they should just play all the missions twice.  The gun customization is really lacking; most ammo types are unavailable unless you specifically build you gun to accept them, and nearly every combination slows your character's movement to an unplayable crawl.It says a lot about the overall quality of the game that I can still recommend it, despite these awful downsides.  However, this is a very tentative recommendation; I bet there's plenty of people out there that would take those as enough red flags to stay away from Mercenary Kings.  Just download Cheat Engine and hack yourself a huge stockpile of crafting materials, and you'll enjoy the game so much more, I promise.

												I don't know if I'm just bad at this game or it's just how it's programmed. Right off the back, the game's art style is the major thing that caught my attention. As an insult to injury, you will lose a chunk of money you will earn by completing the mission. When you die too many times the mission will end and you will be taken back to the main hub. It seems like the game is punishing you by not giving you any variety of weapons to buy, even at the first three missions, making it incredibly difficult to beat any of the missions. I don't know how the game is further in deph, since I dropped my controller and turned it off after attempting the first three missions and failing all of them at least twice. Overall I do not recommend this game to anyone who will play it alone, it is clearly meant for co-op, if they can even manage to scrape the surface of the first three missions.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Boiling it down to "Metal Slug meets Borderlands" is a pretty good way to sum it up, though not perfect: while equipment (namely, gun) choices can have an insane level of variety and custimation, there's no random generation involved like borderlands. Each gun part has specific stats, the parts needed to craft them consistently drop from certain foes or items boxes in a given mission. The only RNG involved is hoping a monster will drop the material you need from the 2-4 predefined drops in their loot pool.All in all, Mercenary Kings takes old school, tough side-scrolling shooters of the past (think metal slug, contra) and blends it with more modern RPG customization elements. Gear selection in a sidescroller isn't all that new, just look all the way back to river city ransom, but the incredible level of customization you can access to make cool guns definitely gives it a modern touch and adds a lot of depth. Add an enjoyable semi-retro 2D sprite art-style, a fun story/setting that doesn't take itself too seriously, and last but not least, local and online co-op,  and you have a well-rounded game with a lot of replay value.

Posted: April 9, 2014
												A solid 2D action game.  Some may describe it as a run and gun, but it has a much more deliberate pace.  While the learning curve may initially be a bit steep, the game provides a moderate challenge all the way through.  Rush or play carelessly and you will be punished.  The game expects you to learn the patterns of your enemies.  Positioning and purposeful movement are key.  The controls are crisp, but a controller would be highly recommended in this case.  I played using a Wii U Pro controller.It is broken up into short missions which can usually be completed in 5-10 minutes each.  These missions are on a timer, but for the most part these timers are very generous.  However, if you are the kind of player who cannot stand having time limits you may want to avoid this game.  The missions come in a number of varieties.  Collect materials, kill a boss, clear out the enemies, or reach a destination.The art is incredibly well done, the entire game looks great.  The sound track can be quite catchy too.  The presentation is superb in every way.The gun crafting system is can be quite entertaining for those who like to tinker.  While initially the options are limited after completing a few ranks you can start mising and matching.  Machine guns that shoot bouncy balls, fire based shotguns, and electric homing missile machine guns are all possible.  You can find a weapon to suit your style.  While Shotguns and Sniper Rifles are a bit dominate in the early game as you progress pretty much everything becomes viable.If you are willing to put in a little effort to learn the game it will be a solid experience.  However, you need to be ready for a game that can be a bit challenging and does not hold your hand.

												Mercenary Kings is a pretty weird game in how it mixes the old and new in game design. Side-scrolling 2D shoot-em-up? Check. Gorgeous, elaborate pixel art? Check. Elaborate gun crafting systtem? Uh, check. Active reloads? Check. It's an odd combination, certainly, but it mostly manages to work. The actual issues with the game are more of the "mileage may vary" sort. If you actually care about unique mission structure, this isn't the game for you. Each mission follows one of maybe ten basic types, the differences between individual missions of a type being more based in mad libs requirements than anything more substantial. Swapping out one enemy set or materials checklist for another. For me personally, I don't mind. That's because the joy of the game isn't in accomplishing the objectives, but kicking♥♥♥♥♥much♥♥♥♥♥as possible with a customized loadout that grows increasingly ridiculous as you unlock new parts. Completing the missions is only a means to an end. That being said, it is a repetitive game at the best of times. It just manages to be repetitive in a way I enjoy, Your tolerance may be substantially lower. Keep that in mind before you decide whether to make the leap.

Posted: March 28, 2014
												Pretty good game. At first I was incredibly impressed by how polished and wonderful it looks (because it does - it has that fantastic Metal Slug feel to its presentation), and by how fun the simple gameplay is. It's a lot of fun to traverse the non-linear levels, and most enemies are pretty fun to fight and kill.However, after playing for a few hours, I started to realize how much content is recycled, and how tiring it got that every mission is just a fetch quest. On the same couple of levels. This hit especially hard when I played a mission where you have to hunt down a boss that keeps escaping to different points on the level, making him almost impossible to find let alone kill (I had to find him four times in random spots before I was able to wear him down). A few missions later, they recycled the *exact* same boss and level, with the only difference being that you had to stun and capture him or something.I really wish the game didn't have so much excess padding, because it could've been one of my favorite indie titles ever. I have a few other gripes, such as the fact that it's pretty bad at explaining how all the customization works, and if you finish the main objective in a level you get no chance to finish the secondary before leaving. Also, the reload mechanic slows down the pace a lot, and makes single-shot guns very unfun.Still, it's a strong game at its core, and tons of fun outside of the annoying moments. It's not worth its full price because you're gonna get sick of it pretty fast, but on a sale for like 3-5€? Sure.

												Mercenary Kings is one of the few games that depicts how only a few mechanics can throw a monkey wrench into what could have been a great game. From the start you are given a game that is a mix of Monster Hunter,Metal Slug, and a dash of Gears of War. In theory this sounds quite awesome! In practice it shows how each one of these mechanics can work against each other.      Starting with the Monster Hunter mechanic of finding loot to craft new guns, this forces the player to grind in a side scrolling shooter. At first it dose not seem to be an issue up until you face the 2nd boss in which kill you. Or in most cases, will time you out. Causes you to replay stages for better weapons because bosses in the game can run away from you if you don't kill them fast enough. Next is the two other mechanics described in which can work against each other.    Due the reload mechanic you will be taking shots and you have no way to defend yourself. This could have been fixed with an instant reload rather than the timed reload. Adding another layer of frusteration. I tried going in wanting to love it. Even through the time on greenlight I tried holding hope. Sadly I can't say it is fun sadly. I give Mercenary Kings a 6.5/10.

												Fantastically fun, delightfully addictive, visually charming, reasonably challenging, compellingly deep. The gameplay is very reminiscent of side scrolling action games like Metal Slug, but with material drops on enemy kills and in chests, etc. Rather than build levels in the traditional sense, your ranking and what missions you have completed determine what missions are available,  what areas are available, and what weapon parts become available as progress is made; Therein lies the sense of progression and accomplishment. You’ll find yourself repeating missions to farm certain materials, but the grind never really feels repetitive. Building new gun parts and outfitting the new crafted weapons with new ammunition is always fun. The build your own weapon mechanic is surprisingly deep as there is no one right way to build. Same goes for crafting the knife weapons, though they are a little more straightfoward. Fun all around, no complaints, would recommend.

												This game isn't what you think it is.  You probably think it's Metal Slug with customizable guns, which sounds fantastic.  I'd love to play that game.  That's not what this is.  You're not going to run around like a maniac blowing up everything around you.  What you're actually going to do is move carefully forward so you don't get hit, explore every corner of the map over and over, and ultimately get tired and give up.  The main gameplay loop is that you have to move carefully or take damage, which is *very* expensive to repair, and many of the missions involve finding 10 of something on the map...and there's only 10 to find.  And they're not listed on the map.  So you end up exploring the map over and over until you have 9 of 10 collected and you can't find the last one, so you end up going over and over the map, taking damage and dying until eventually you either run out of lives or out of time, and these missions aren't short.  You will put a HUGE ammount of time into these missions and fail them over and over.  Plus you can't alt-tab out of the game, so you can't even look at FAQs or maps to help you.  The game doesn't make you feel strong, it makes you feel like a chump.  The grind takes forever and unless you enjoy finding items scattered and hidden all over the same map over and over, you'll eventually grow to hate it.  I did.  I can't recommend this game.

												A reboot of those old-school action packed platformers. But with RPG elements, like crafting your own prefered equipment. Sounds good right? Well this game is not very good. It is boring.The problem is threefold:- you now need to "grind" materials for upgrades. And then you need to build a bunch of random stuff to unlock proficiencies. I got bored with this system and the available options about 10 missions in. Surely late game stuff might be nice and all, it is an unattractive system early on. Especially because you have no idea where you should be farming in the first place.- the maps are the same, over and over again. Same enemies, but that is not all, they are applied in a very repetetive way as well. Sniper on a ledge where you need to get close, rifleman jumping down on you, spearmen attacking from above, drill in a hole, metal drone when you zipline down. Repeat 20 times every stage. There, spoiled the first 3 maps, on which you do at least 3-5 missions each. Boring and annoying.- the "quests" you get to do are boring. Gather 10 of this. (random drops or in boxes, so walk around the entire map. Again) Go to this NPC. And even the Boss, which could have been interesting, is annoying and boring. He moves from the scene at random. So you have to go through the level you got to know by heart by now, AGAIN to find he moves away after just one attack, so you have to track him down AGAIN.Oh and it gets worse: Then you get to do that boss AGAIN. Same map, same fight, but now you have to finish with a shock grenade. Which is the first time you get to use these, they are hard to use, you get only three, so then if you fail to get it right 3 times, you can just as well go and restart the map. After two runs so facing and beating this boss 3 times I had enough.No more waiting in an infirmary for 50 seconds (!?!) to heal up, no more cleaning up / skipping the same enemies 20 times over and finding that you have 50/9 for one craftin component and 1/2 out of some random rare drop you never can seem to find.3/10, would not be bored by again.

												I highly recommend this game to anyone who was, or is, a fan of metal slug. This game uses similar mechanics, but also does away with intsa-death, for you and your enemies.It also adds further depth with customization options, such as knife-type, gun-types, ammo-types, and bionic mods (akin to passive boosts).Although the campaign does run a acceptable length of time, some people may find the levels repetitive - you are required to do several missions (about 7) per area, and you will revisit the same areas. Posted: January 20, 2014
												I bought this game in Early Access and quickly played through all the available missions. At one point I was disappointed at the lack of new weapons as the game progressed but when I checked back again even that problem was solved with an update, the weapon count had probably doubled. So I made myself a couple of Magnum-shotguns (not making this up!), a pistol that would shoot armor-piercing shrapnel once the ammo was possible to obtain (It needs a material that doesn't drop yet, Quality Steel or something) and Anti-Materiel rounds that have yet to see a weapon that can fire them. Can't wait for the full game, I'll probably 100% it.TotalBiscuit described this game as "Metal Slug meets Monster Hunter" and I agree. The Monster Hunter part comes from all the crafting. Biomods, melee weapons, guns, ornaments... everything apart from your supplies has to be crafted from materials that drop from enemies and crates scattered across different missions and especially with some materials you WILL have to farm them. (Like those surprisingly special "regular pins".) The magnum shotguns I mentioned before required parts that only drop from big story bosses. Speaking of bosses, they are as classic as they get. Very punishing if you don't know what you're doing (the first time always hurts) but once you have their patterns down with some good reflexes it's as easy as breathing.The keyboard bindings need some work but luckily you can bind any key to whatever you want. I recommend using a controller, though.

												So far so good!  For the old school gamers who came up on platform shooters like Contra, you'll LOVE this.  It's as if Contra, Metal Slug, and Loadout made a baby.  I know I often mash up games like this for my review, but I like to be as vivid as possible to make sure you fully understand.  The basics of Contra, the humor and style of Metal Slug, and the customization of Loadout is what you will get.  Unlike platformers I've played in the past, this one allows each player to take their own path!  No more compromising on which way to go first so that the other player doesn't get killed or stuck by the edge of the screen.  The only downside to it so far, is the time limit for each mission.  There's so much I want to explore within the level, and it's easy to forget about the time limit on completing your objective.

												Mercenary Kings is an interesting game. It takes Metal Slug style graphics and gameplay, introduces an almost Monster Hunter style crafting system, and a fun skill-based reloading system that can jam your gun or give you extra damage. I love the soundtrack, sounding at times like a cross between Mega Man and Doom. I love the variety of guns and builds. I had a ton of fun playing this game and you may too if all this sounds appealing to you.However, the game is not perfect. As many have stated, the levels and missions can be very repetitive. Much of the game consists of exploring the map, collecting items, saving NPCs, and fighting mini-bosses. There isn't really much storyline or variety in gameplay at all. The price is a bit steep for what you're getting here, but I personally love the game regardless. Wait until it goes on sale or goes in a bundle and try it out if you think the pros outweigh the cons.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												The bad:- Controls are really clunky. The response time from jump button pressed to actual jump happening takes a second. You literally need to see into the future in order to jump over bullets.- Reload system is the bane of this gameSeriously, having a Guitar Hero "Press reload as the cursor hits green" system is just distracting. I have to dodge 4 bullets in a row and if I don't press the reload button my reload time will get longer, and if i press wrongly my gun jams? That's just punishing, no matter how you debate this. And this happened on the first mission already.- Item pickup. I see the need to share the crafting materials amongst friends but isn't trading after battle more intuitive? What's more, you have to go over to the item, press down to pick it up, and risk getting shot at from a one-eyed joe from far. It really is punishing to collect items for crafting.- Confusing. Map. System.Many of the rooms exist in the game to pad the gametime. Really. 6 rooms that exist for no good reason are there just so they can hide a hostage in one of them. And the map doesn't really help considering that the map doesn't indicate clearly which doorway links to the next map. It serves to confuse.- Confusing. Objectives.I know your testers have played this game a million times, but at least let a first timer know how a HOSTAGE looks like? When was the last time you saw a commando take off to save the President without knowing how he LOOKS like?And while we are on the missions, why do I need to go over to the helicopter to start the mission when the Colonel already yelled at me to start the mission? Isn't that a wrapper within a wrapper of a candy? And its always a conensus in multiplayer that when someone starts a mission, everyone wants the mission to-go? You already did the "press A" confirmation at character select, you can always do it again for mission selection.- Some scenary really stands out. Too much.Some of the wooden pillars blend in too well with the foreground so much so that I mistook them as platforms. And died. This becomes a game of memory rather than a platformer reflex shooter.The Good:- Artstyle.The lighthearted style gives you the remniscent Metal Gear nostalgia: Light hearted fun, run 'n' gun, nothing much to think about.- The Gun.The RPG style of upgrading your gun and your knife gives you the warm fuzzy feeling every RPG player has known and love. Though the ingredients farming can get grindy at times.Overall, this game lacks the polish of Metal Slug that it clearly is inspired by. The gun upgrade adds flavour to the game but as a reflex Run'n'Gun player, this game fails to live up to my expectation mainly due to its lack of responsive controls and disruption of flow of the gameplay. Mainly, the reload mechanism. Seriously, remove it. The boost isn't even worth hitting the Green Area.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												A dastardly cross of  gameplay from Metal Slug and Contra, with more RPG typical features like persistent equipment, crafting, and character upgrades. Interesting gun mechanics, and pretty slick 16-bit (ish) aesthetics make it a delight to play. The story is pretty minimal, but the writing is very funny, and continual references to other games make for great "AH! I GET IT! THAT'S FROM _____!" moments. Also: local and online co-op. It has both. The game doesn't change at all between solo and co-op play however, so everything becomes much easier with others.BUT: somewhat repetitive. There are over 100 individual objective based missions, but they take place on a much smaller number of actual maps, and going around the same maps many times can get boring. Add in the farming that inevitably occurs when you're trying to get parts for a specific gun part or implant or knife, and it can get a little tedious.Overall great game, especially for fans of old school run and gun sidescrolling shooters.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												Crafting is one of the worst plagues upon modern gaming, and here is one of its worst itinerations.  The missions often take place in the same few maps, merely putting the start and finish lines in different areas.  The reload mechanic is completely out of place in a game like this.  Boss fights are the worst because said bosses will randomly leave the area and require you to track them down anew.  The music is a confused mess, unsure of whether it wants to go full chiptune or not.  The overall goal is also muddled; the game rewards you for speedrunning missions, and also for taking time to explore and fulfill extra objectives, leaving players wondering if they should just play all the missions twice.  The gun customization is really lacking; most ammo types are unavailable unless you specifically build you gun to accept them, and nearly every combination slows your character's movement to an unplayable crawl.It says a lot about the overall quality of the game that I can still recommend it, despite these awful downsides.  However, this is a very tentative recommendation; I bet there's plenty of people out there that would take those as enough red flags to stay away from Mercenary Kings.  Just download Cheat Engine and hack yourself a huge stockpile of crafting materials, and you'll enjoy the game so much more, I promise.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Boiling it down to "Metal Slug meets Borderlands" is a pretty good way to sum it up, though not perfect: while equipment (namely, gun) choices can have an insane level of variety and custimation, there's no random generation involved like borderlands. Each gun part has specific stats, the parts needed to craft them consistently drop from certain foes or items boxes in a given mission. The only RNG involved is hoping a monster will drop the material you need from the 2-4 predefined drops in their loot pool.All in all, Mercenary Kings takes old school, tough side-scrolling shooters of the past (think metal slug, contra) and blends it with more modern RPG customization elements. Gear selection in a sidescroller isn't all that new, just look all the way back to river city ransom, but the incredible level of customization you can access to make cool guns definitely gives it a modern touch and adds a lot of depth. Add an enjoyable semi-retro 2D sprite art-style, a fun story/setting that doesn't take itself too seriously, and last but not least, local and online co-op,  and you have a well-rounded game with a lot of replay value.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Mercenary Kings (MK) is a perfect blend that is so rarely come across these days.  At a glance, it may remind you of Metal Slug - and, at a very surface level, it does bring you that feeling and experience, however, MK is far more than that.MK introduces several new and refreshing concepts to the classic run-and-gun platfomer.  As you defeat enemies, you pick up material drops.  These are used to craft weapon and armour upgrades, knives, and well as character "perks" if you will.  Though I'm not through the game, there are probably thousands of unique weapon configurations that can be created by mixing and matching different parts that you have created.  Armour upgrades are much more vanilla, a simple "material for boost" trade.  Armour upgrades are linear, and one-piece progression.Weapon crafting deserves a bit more talk.  The gun consists of several different parts, each of which may effect weight, range, power, clip-size, shot distance, reload speed, and special effect (armour piercing, caustic, electric, etc.).  Each part also has its own designed graphic which shows up as you play.  This allows some pretty zany and custom options for you to pick from.  You may also choose to build your gun as a "set" by picking each piece that matches the same name - there are some advantages to playing that way as well.As for missions - there are A LOT of them to get through.  Missions are based on a few categories.  You've got your side quests and your primary quests, but they're also broken down by ranking.  You'll need to complete the main quests of one group before the next batch of missions are unlocked.  I can't see any reason to skip the side-missions, though, as you will collect a lot of valuable resources and cash to advance through the game more smoothly.Though the price of the game may seem a bit steep, you can really tell that A LOT of work has gone into creating this title - there's more content than I can list in one sitting, and there are PLENTY of missions to keep you going.  If you can't afford the $20, I certainly suggest grabbing it while it's on sale.  There are only a few games that have piqued my interest and hooked me in as well as this one has.  Kudos to the devs.

												Mercenary Kings is a pretty fun and cute little side scrolling platforming game. The animations for the sprite graphics is pretty damn good and sometimes very fluid. Posted: November 1, 2015
The GoodAs advertised, this is a 2D shooter / scroller / run around the map a roller with plenty of gun customization.The music is pretty good and the pixel art graphics and animations done by Paul Robertson, among the best in that field, are absolute eye-candy to look at. If you've ever played or seen Scott Pilgrim Vs. The World The Game on consoles, you've seen some of this guy's work already. The basic gameplay works fine enough with you jumpin', runnin', knifin' and shootin' (not diagonally though) through an assortment of levels with a bunch of goodies hidden about. When you get into the groove and master the controls it can definitely trigger some nostalgia from cartridge/arcade cabinet days of yesteryear.The BadTo deck out those guns and upgrade your gear, you're going to have to do quite a bit of grinding for ingredients (random drop or otherwise). Expect to revisit a bunch of areas for this purpose and have to deal with monotonous mission objectives, time-limits and silly boss fights where you have to worry about tracking them down across the whole map to fight them some more until they die if you take too long. All while the timer ticks down in the background. No pressure to find your way to one of those boss arenas scattered about the maze-like maps while the boss periodically shuffles around (leading to some particularly cruel instances where you can finally make it to a boss-zone where it's at and it just walks away after three seconds) or anything. There may additionally be some problems with the game on certain monitors or comps but I didn't personally run into this myselfThe UglyEven with this game's short-comings, there IS fun to be had. As such, there is definitely an audience or two to reccomend this to. Just be prepared to have a bit more Monster Hunter in your Metal Slug sandwich than you perhaps initially bargained for. Replace the Mission Complete jingle with the one from Metal Slug via files for maximum irony while you're at it, too.

Posted: January 15, 2015
												Does blasting an army of bad guys to smithereens Metal Slug-style sound like your idea of a good time? How about doing it with your own custom-made weapon using whatever mishmash of parts you can think of? If any of that appeals to you, then this is absolutely worth a shot.Paul Robertson's handmade sprites and backdrops do a lot to give the experience that retro/fake-retro charm without coming across as just pixelated for the sake of it. The soundtrack's combination of metal and chiptune-like tones calls to mind things like Virt's compositions for Contra 4 and DuckTales Remastered.Once you get some momentum going, it's lots of fun crafting gun parts, bionic mods and even substitutes for your trusty knife, to put together your own personal loadout and see how it performs.There's a couple hitches though. To me at least, the system of equipment weighing you down seems out of place, and the Monster Hunter-type layout of missions giving you different objectives in the same areas means it can get kind of repetitive, especially if there's a gun part or something you REALLY want to get the materials for.Trifles aside, it's a fine example of mashing together run-and-gun violence and strategic weapon crafting.

Like the whole thing is just a really really thick skeleton...What I'm trying to say is that the game is samey as ♥♥♥♥. Like pretty badly. The crafting system, while not terribly unique, really adds a sense of depth and personalization to the game, and lets you set goals for yourself, which is always a plus in my book. But the reason I recommend this is not any of that. I'm giving this a recommendation because it is just a much cooler version of Metal Slug, and I like Metal Slug. I might not want to play it all the time, but when I do this game is there for me with a mission I haven't completed the fastest time on or a new gun that I haven't beaten a boss with or just something, anything, to give me an excuse to play a very functional, responsive, fun 2-D scrolling shooter. And at the end of the day, that's worth the 20 (15 if you have friends) dollars.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2015
												I don't think the game deserves so many negative reviews, even though I understand their overall issues, Mercenary Kings' pros easily outweigh it's cons.Mercenary Kings is a load of fun, highly polished with much more depth than it appears at first glance.The level design works through missions in 1-2 levels per rank (there's 10 ranks), with enough variation to keep you entertained, yet enough repetition so you can learn the levels and enjoy the benefits of improving with experience.The game rewards your patience with a highly satisfying control system that gets better as you do, and a very enjoyable mechanic where you unlock weapon parts to customise your arsenal. As you progress, rarer hidden parts become vital to unlocking the best weapons, which offers great replayability.It's fair to say taht the game does get a bit samey at times, and some of the levels can feel like a chore to replay, but overall I found this effect rather minimal to my enjoyment.I should also add that I bought this game on sale, and would feel more comfortable recommending it around the $10 price range, rather than the $20. Also, I think you will enjoy the game a lot more if you have friends to play it with. While the single player is great, I think the game shines at sharing your mix of weapons and working together to explore the map and bring down the bosses.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2014
												This game is incredibly fun. Think Monster Hunter + Metal Slug. You kill enemies which drop resources that you use to build parts for guns, build melee weapons, or make mods which give various effects. Granted, most missions are gathering missions, but there is a small variety. Sometimes you will need to kill a boss, or even capture it with Shock Bombs when it is low on health.You only shoot in the cardinal directions, which I am fine with. It would be too easy if you could aim diagonally. The jumping takes a bit to get used to. Just as a reference, think Batman on the NES. The jump works almost the exact same. A slight delay before jumping, hold it down to jump higher, and once you're in the air you can alter the trajectory slightly.Most missions have bonus objectives, and every mission has Secret objectives which are only revealed once you have found/killed whatever the secret objective is related to. Bonus and secret objectives offer bonus money and resources.This game is very grind-heavy, since you have to hope for resource drops, but it's much more forgiving than a lot of other games. Some missions offer a few of a specific resource, or the mission actually requires you find that resource. A simple look through the resource guide in the community hub can help you find that elusive resource. I'd recommend this game to any fan of Metal Slug-style games, or even just side-scrolling shooters. Hell, I'd recommend it to anyone, really. As always, if you're not sure, watch some gameplay videos of it.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												Platforming old-school style! This is classic style gaming at it's finest. It brings back memories of game arcades and early home consoles.The mechanics are a bit primataive (no diagonal shooting) but the game seems well ballanced around that.The story is also classic. You fight an evil organization bent on...world domination? Terrorists? Bad guys for sure at any rate. You start play as one of two previous mission/story survivors brought back to life by a specially formulated serum, which is probably why the island you are on was invaded in the first place. Everyone wants it.Gather the items your enemies drop when defeated and use them to create new weapon parts and other implements of destruction and warfare. Missions pay well the more successful you are, some even have bonus objectives. You can buy supplies (rations, first aid kits etc.)  to take with you into the field or chance finding what you need as you go.Games were never this complex in the old days since back then, it was all about the high score. Modern game design, such as the custom weapons, keep the game fresh in modern times.

												As much as I love Tribute Games' amazing pixel-art and audio, it's hard to recommend this game because of how repetitive it gets.As per your standard "loot treadmill" loop, you will be exploring the same areas repeatedly while collecting crafting-goop that you use to craft better equipment. There's nothing inherently wrong with this formula, but I don't feel it worked for me in Mercenary Kings, because I got tired of the same 2-4 areas really quickly, and all the quests felt like filler. I also got really tired of picking-up crafting-material from everything, and didn't derive much joy from experimenting with various weapon/equipment combinations.The first 2 hours of the game were really enjoyable for me, mostly because of the gorgeous aesthetics and good sound-design, but eventually monotony just took over and I had to stop.
