content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												Combat is cumbersome and contrived. Controlling your character is a chore due to speed, the poor hit direction of your attacks, and the delay of movement you suffer after landing a freaking jump. The gameplay is far from "frantic"—deliberating your every move before jumping in to combat b/c of your own movement limitations is just inexcusable. Perpetually spawning enemies can be bland: they either spawn right in front of a doorway, or in the exact same spot they were killed a minute before. Search and rescue/destroy missions take forever due the circular level design in some areas.Ironically, MK really shines with it's non-Platformer elements. I love the idea of crafting weapon upgrades from found materials and dealing elemental damage. The reloading system is surprisingly fun: time your reloads, and dispatch your foes with high powered rounds of ammunition. Of course, the multiplayer is a plus, albeit a standard one.Part of me thinks I've just been spoiled by the gameplay of Metal Slug, but there are so many things that MK can do so much better. As it is, I cannot recommend Mercenary Kings, even with the $5 discount. Here's to hoping for a more polished edition after development is complete.

Posted: June 2, 2015
												A sidescrolling shooter with retro grafics and custom weapons.GameplayThere is a bunch of bigger maps. Your missions are normaly set in a part of the map. Most of the time you have to kill something or search something. Different missions require different strategies and equipement. You may call it a little bit repetitive, but it works. The real thing in this game is the weapon customization/crafting: You can build different gun parts and combine them as you like. Scoped assault rifle? Armourpiercing Miningun? Homing SMG? Sniper-SMG? Shotgun-Pistol? There are no limits (almost).Grafics & SoundThe grafics are charming and functual. It's retro style but in a really good way. No pseudo-retro pixel war, nope. Its clean pixel art. The sound matches this perfectly: reminds me of the old console times.DifficultyOk i have to stress that: the start is quite challanging and a little bit frustrating. But soon you will be able to upgrade your gun. From this moment it gets easier. Mid-Game is playable and fun but in the end, well it gets quite hard again... but its perfectly playable. I played the complete game on solo: its possible but you have to think a little bit and train your fingers!Pros:-Custom weapons (play it your style)-Different play styles are possible-Lots uf parts to unlock-Diffent maps (Horizontal street parts, vertical parts in buildings, jump&run like parts)-Challanging (I take it as a pro, but you might take it otherwise)Cons:-First trys may be a little bit hard-Missions can by quite repetitive (kill X soliders, gather X minerals...)In a nutshell: On of the few sidescrolling shooters i really enjoy. Weapon-Crafing is fun and offers a lot of variety!

												Is this a great game in the traditional sense? Debatable. There's definitely the skeleton of an amazing game, but it's hard to deny that the flesh is basically made out of bone. Like the whole thing is just a really really thick skeleton...What I'm trying to say is that the game is samey as ♥♥♥♥. Like pretty badly. The boss fights are nicely varied, but the missions in between are just... you'll know a map front to back at the end of it's related rank, that's for damn sure. The crafting system, while not terribly unique, really adds a sense of depth and personalization to the game, and lets you set goals for yourself, which is always a plus in my book. But the reason I recommend this is not any of that. I'm giving this a recommendation because it is just a much cooler version of Metal Slug, and I like Metal Slug. I might not want to play it all the time, but when I do this game is there for me with a mission I haven't completed the fastest time on or a new gun that I haven't beaten a boss with or just something, anything, to give me an excuse to play a very functional, responsive, fun 2-D scrolling shooter. And at the end of the day, that's worth the 20 (15 if you have friends) dollars.

Posted: February 10, 2015
												This game breathes life back into the metal slug side scrolling shooters that in my opinion we could all use more of.  This game not only brings it back, but adds an rpg element as well as the most in depth gun crafting system I've seen in awhile.  The game is not only pretty in its animations, the backgrounds and level design really give you a sense of going back to the metal slug days with its sprites.  Theirs an intense list of gun parts, knives, and missions to choose from, and 100 percent completionists are going to be overwhelmed with the amount of content in this game.  However:  The game feels almost too long for what it is, and that feeling will come when you notice alot of the enemies, levels, and mission types are reused.  In my opinion the game would be sweeter if the reskinned enemies, and missions were reduced to preserve the flavor.  That and the timelimit to each level.  I could see how that would necessary for speed completionists and the like, but with the world so massive and the map telling little of the location of your objective sometimes, it can be frustrating and you may find yourself losing 20+plus minutes only to fail at your mission due to the timer.  This as well as the outright useless of the grenade and severly limited item carrying capacity, leaves me a peeved at certain times. (especially when half of the items are needed to advance or complete the mission)All an all it is still a great game, and worth every penny for the sheer quanity of game you get!  its nice to see this genre back up and running again, and kickstarted no less!

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												One of the best Shoot'em up I've ever played (probably the best). Scenario Well, really, there's a bad guy who wants to do bad things, and you have to beat his a**.Mercenary Kings takes place in a wild lonely wild island where a super-vilain has decided to build his super-vilain's base.It offers (from the top of my head) approximately 7 differents sceneries, from the wild jungle to the full-of-traps temple, or even a high-tech complex. Graphics You like or dislike this kind of graphics, but I actually love it. "Pixel-art"-like graphics are, in my opinon, a standard for this kind of games, and it suits very well with the features and gameplay it offers (even animated boobs, no jokes). Gamplay Easy to learn, pretty easy to master (at least master on specific type of weapon / ammo). I personnaly used an xBox 360 controller from the very beginning, so I cannot relly talk about the Keyboard / Mouse controls.Controls are intuitive, and even if it's not at the beginning, you really have the time to master it.Mercenary Kings is quest-based, with a "Hunting ground" (aka time / quest-free zone) where you can hunt animals and such to get missings compenents for your gear.It offers a crafting system for your guns. You have to build from components a parts of weapons, then you can assemble whatever part of any gun you like together, it will make a working gun (probably not as working as you expected).Some weapons have a certain "synergy", making you able to use special ammo (6 differents types) like shrapnels or rockets, and sometimes two of them at the same time (piercing rockets, omfg).You can also build knifes, which I thought to be unless, does really matters from middle to end-game.There's equipable "mods", which makes you carry more, run faster, shoot elemental bullets, or even makes you insensitive to certain elements.I don't really want to talk about the rest of the features, since it would probable spoil a bit. Multiplayer I didn't test multiplayer yet, I will update this review as soon as I tested it. General impressions Like I said, probably the best Shoot'em up I've ever played. I did finish the last mission, but I would really enjoy play this more. There's a really great amount of quest, stuff to craft, secrets to discover, and all kind of things.I didn't find anything that really upset me here.I'm kinda sad I couldn't test multiplayer yet, but as I see it, it would be as epic as the rest of this game.Note: 10/10. (Really.)N.B.: As a non-native english speaker, I apologize for any mistakes / bad words or such in this review.

Posted: November 11, 2015
												A dastardly cross of  gameplay from Metal Slug and Contra, with more RPG typical features like persistent equipment, crafting, and character upgrades. Interesting gun mechanics, and pretty slick 16-bit (ish) aesthetics make it a delight to play. The story is pretty minimal, but the writing is very funny, and continual references to other games make for great "AH! I GET IT! THAT'S FROM _____!" moments. Also: local and online co-op. It has both. The game doesn't change at all between solo and co-op play however, so everything becomes much easier with others.BUT: somewhat repetitive. There are over 100 individual objective based missions, but they take place on a much smaller number of actual maps, and going around the same maps many times can get boring. Add in the farming that inevitably occurs when you're trying to get parts for a specific gun part or implant or knife, and it can get a little tedious.Overall great game, especially for fans of old school run and gun sidescrolling shooters.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2014
												Really fun game! I found myself actually wanting to play it!Apparently it's a lot like Monster Hunter? I don't know. I've never played Monster Hunter. The look and theme is very Metal Slug, but it doesn't play like Metal Slug at all. This does not make it bad, it just makes it a different genre.Positives:1. Wonderful pixel art in all its pixelated glory. Seriously I'm not even kidding. The artwork is absolutely beautiful and completely functional. You can tell every different enemy or friendly apart instantly.2. Tons of customization! You can customize your gun, knives, inventory, etc. to a great degree, allowing lots of potential.3. Perfect learning curve. The game gives you a little taste of customization when you start out that gradually gets deeper and more indepth so the player doesn't feel overwhelmed at first.4. Not a short game. There are lots of stages that give you variety.5. The story is tight and focused. You're a soldier in an army trying to beat some terrorist because he's a jerk. There are a lot of amusing NPCs who are your back-up team. It's stylized a little like Metal Gear Solid (there are 'codec'-like conversations), but it's not crazy-complicated. You can fully ignore it if you want.Negatives:1. It's a resource-gathering game. The core game mechanic is killing an enemy then picking up whatever junk is left behind, then doing this a thousand more times. Can't ignore it or you'll never get the better guns. Ho-hum.Nitpicks:1. For each mission, you have a primary objective, a secondary objective, then a secret objective that the game doesn't tell you about. When you complete the primary objective, the mission ends and forcefully brings you back to the base, even if you want to spend time on the other objectives. It'd be nice if you could, say, complete the primary objective and then choose when you want to end the mission (or just wait for the timer).Overall a very solid game. Recommended.

												This game is basically Contra + Monster Hunter.  If that sounds interesting, give it a chance.  It's definitely a game I had to get used to and wasn't what I expected at first. content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Mercenary Kings (MK) is a perfect blend that is so rarely come across these days.  At a glance, it may remind you of Metal Slug - and, at a very surface level, it does bring you that feeling and experience, however, MK is far more than that.MK introduces several new and refreshing concepts to the classic run-and-gun platfomer.  As you defeat enemies, you pick up material drops.  These are used to craft weapon and armour upgrades, knives, and well as character "perks" if you will.  Though I'm not through the game, there are probably thousands of unique weapon configurations that can be created by mixing and matching different parts that you have created.  Armour upgrades are much more vanilla, a simple "material for boost" trade.  Armour upgrades are linear, and one-piece progression.Weapon crafting deserves a bit more talk.  The gun consists of several different parts, each of which may effect weight, range, power, clip-size, shot distance, reload speed, and special effect (armour piercing, caustic, electric, etc.).  Each part also has its own designed graphic which shows up as you play.  This allows some pretty zany and custom options for you to pick from.  You may also choose to build your gun as a "set" by picking each piece that matches the same name - there are some advantages to playing that way as well.As for missions - there are A LOT of them to get through.  Missions are based on a few categories.  You've got your side quests and your primary quests, but they're also broken down by ranking.  You'll need to complete the main quests of one group before the next batch of missions are unlocked.  I can't see any reason to skip the side-missions, though, as you will collect a lot of valuable resources and cash to advance through the game more smoothly.Though the price of the game may seem a bit steep, you can really tell that A LOT of work has gone into creating this title - there's more content than I can list in one sitting, and there are PLENTY of missions to keep you going.  If you can't afford the $20, I certainly suggest grabbing it while it's on sale.  There are only a few games that have piqued my interest and hooked me in as well as this one has.  Kudos to the devs.

												Oh boy I was happy when I saw that Humble Bundle, but sadly the game dissappointed me.I will make a comparision with Yoshi´ Island and Yoshi Story, because it reflects the best way, why this game doesn´t make any fun for me.In Yoshis Island all the collecting is optional, the main goal is to reach the end. 												Metal Slug with Crafting.Mercenary Kings is side scrolling shoot um up done in the style of retro arcade classics like Metal Slug.  The Hook however is in this game is your can select and replay different missions, have a health bar, and collect items that you can use back at base to upgrade your character and weapons.  The crafting works well.  There are a crap ton of varations for your gun and the game does a decent job of pacing bigger and better upgrades.  The Game looks great. Alot of them feel same'y.  Get x amount of this item or search and destroy a boss. or kill x amount of x enemy.  It gets a bit old.  One of the reasons that games like Metal Gear hold up is that they were always throwing new and crazy stuff at you.  In Mercenary Kings things ramp up too slowly.  Also i'm not a fan of having timed missions.Overall this is a fun enough time waster that, if you want, you can sink hours of time into.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2015
												The Good:Very well done retro 2D shooterVery powerful gun customization systemLots of stuff to craftThe Bad:Poor tutorial, you really need to read the in-game manual on the main menu (which inexplicably is not accessible once you've loaded a charater).Major pacing issues, especially at the beginning. The first part of the game is the most difficult since you haven't unlocked the good stuff yet and haven't memorized the maps yet.Repetitive missions reuse the same maps over and over with slightly different objectives.Enemies can be quite cheap at times (pinning you against a wall, attacking through a wall) and the retro gameplay means you can only shoot in 4 directions even though some enemies come right in on your blind spots.Mission objectives are frequently unmarked and you have to scour the level to find what you're looking for (and hope you know where all the hidden areas are).Reloading is annoying and slow for a run and gun type game.The Ugly:Endless instantly respawning enemies (they respawn as soon as you leave the screen) add a lot of frustration and annoyance when traversing a level for the nth time trying to find an unmarked objective.This game is very close to being amazing, but suffers from a few fatal flaws. None of them would be particularly difficult to fix, but as it stands I can't recommend this game (especially at the asking price) unless you're willing to get past the initial difficulty wall and unlock the good guns.

												Top quality guncrafting gameplay! Honestly that's the biggest reason to get it.The platforming is good, boss design is on point, art is obviously amazing, soundtrack is bangin'. The plot is pretty standard, but the dialogue / characters are both quite well executed.The multiplayer is quite enjoyable, and helps offset the tedium of resource gathering (a core part of the game, at least if you want more gun parts). Posted: April 21, 2014
												This game is the cutting edge of "meh". Played 5 minutes of it with a friend on console, decided to get for PC. Controls are awful for PC and quite frankly it's only good in couch coop, and even then it is indeed limited.I have a lot of gripes with this game, so I'll try to stay constructive where possible, but generally this game is guilty of every "passable" class sin in the book.-Enemies reskinned painfully often.-Static-y AI, bonkers damage. Limited lives that makes you need to go back to camp, load, select your mission, talk to your pilot, and reload the level. Dear god. This is frustrating beyond belief.-Great weapon customization system, but you can totally build weapons WAY too specialized and since you get only 1 gun, special weapons have no real use long term.-Boss reskins. Because why the hell not apparently. This is by far one of the worst sins in the book IMO.-Grindy as hell farming resources and the like. Some missions send you out hunting hostages or resources, and god damn is it boring to all hell. Forget a second playthrough outright. I put 47 hours into the game getting all the things the first go, but attempting a 2nd playthrough is murdering me to death.-Both playable characters (there's only 2) are painfully uninteresting. First playthrough I played the chick because at least she wasn't "rambo clone guy", but even she wasn't a particularly interesting character.-Bosses run away from you after a certain time, and their fights are based off learning attacks almost exclusively. This is a painful combination, but having to jog around the level, find the boss at any of 3 combat points, and re-engage him hoping he doesn't run away in front of your face (because that can happen, too) is absolutely there.-Reused levels and levels generally lacking much in the way of true definition, with a few outlying exceptions.-Virtually non-existant plot, dialogue, and soundtrack from what I can gather. But expect to get talked at about uninteresting crap for hours anyways.Look. I liked this game enough to play it through my first go, but coming back, every sin in this game is magnified exponentially. This game is long, uninteresting, and littered with so many time wasting, sluggish core mechanics I legitimately wonder what the hell they devs were thinking.Crap. I was trying to be constructive. See? It's that hard. Oh well. Detailed negative criticism beats enraged or understaffed negative criticism any day.Save your money. Don't buy this game. It's fun for a few hours, but then all the charm wears off. I legitimately regret buying this game outright.

												wanted to like this game, but majority of the issues with it are due to the developers being unresponsive/outright misadvertising their game. mercenary kings is touted as a multiplayer game, but you're not unlocking the ability to even choose multiplayer options until 8-10 hours into the game. there are also achievement sync issues, which devs have not responded to me when i brought it to their attention. not to mention one of the achievements is literally "you gave over x amount of money to our kickstarter!" (there is an in-game way to get said achievement, but that's missing the point). most importantly, i could forgive the game for being repetivie and grindy since it reuses a lot of the same areas/maps for multiple missions, but the game's overall goal is just kind of a time waster. you get stuff to unlock cosmetic stuff, gun parts (large majority of which you're not using), knives (while useful, again, you're only using one out of the several there are), and various minor upgrades. nothing in the crafting system feels like you're actually /crafting/ anything, just engaging in a glorified merchant system. and while it seems petty to harp on these things, this is largely all the gameplay amounts to.at the end of the day i'd have given this a slightly positive review since the game can be fun (if repetitive), and the art/music shines above the gameplay. but, with the devs being so misleading and unengaging, i can't say it's worth picking up.

Posted: January 13
												Great game, fantastic graphics, superb music, great gameplay.Best played with friends, but beware:  Local co-op is a joke, and the the way that split-screen / menu management works out looks and behaves terrible.  Mutiplayer co-op is a far better experience.  Overall a fun and enjoyable game, but it has some flaws:- It can get very grindy and repetitve around mid-to-late game.  It picks up quick enough for the end-game content, but that mid-game stretch is exhausting. - The levels are repetitive.  The level design is largely superb, but get used to playing them over and over again for different missions.- The crafting system is a great addition but also increases the grindiness tenfold as certain rare materials have depressingly-low drop rates.  A small gameplay change could fix that, I think--giving the player the ability to combine mundane materials together to get quality materials comes to mind--but in lieu of that, get used to checking the wiki early and often.Despite the grindiness, the game ends on a great note, and I highly recommend it.  Here's hoping for a sequel!

												A game that looks like Metal Slug... but don't be fooled.With the best of Paul Robertson's Pixel Artstyle, Mercenary Kings is way more comparable with Mega Man Classics than Metal Slug...Slow-paced combat with very unsatisfying and re-used Bosses... Mercenary Kings drowns in it's own Nostalgia by purposely using only the bad gameplay gimmicks that made 2D games great.Add all that to boring Grinding, Cool-Looking Weapons... that end up just being static models with DMG percentages that aren't worth all of the Grinding.Boss Battles get the more clunky and tiresome approach of Monster Hunter ( this♥♥♥♥♥♥still has fans?! ) where you just study the moveset, wait for the brief windows when you can damage them... and go back to waiting... SNORE!...Mercenary Kings is everything that Metal Slug is not... just get a Metal Slug Bundle and evade this like the Plague.

												It could be good, but it is not.Crafting your own guns is a nice idea and the game offers enough gear to experiment. However, it puts in a barrier of horrible grind for materials and god forgive you craft the wrong stuff and end up with a crappy gun, then you have to use that until you get new materials again.Which would be ok, if the gameplay itself was good enough to not make the grind a horrible experience.But the controls are just the worst ive ever played a game with. Unresponsive, clunky, slow and just bad made.The leveldesign is atrocious, often demanding you to jump so exactly that it becomes bothersome.Oh yeah, and if that wasnt enough, you get a timelimit on your mission AND if you are unlucky you can finish the mission anyway, because you didnt pack in some C4 and cant blow up the door with the objective behind it.Nice hm?Playing missions is ok at first, but really i dont know why i would play them. The best part of this game is crafting your own gung, but playing with that gun is boring at best, and outraging at worst.If the controls and missions were in any way like Metal Slug, this could be the best game ive ever played.But thats not the case.And the bad enemies or bosses, so uninspired, boring and respawning whenever their location gets out of screen, doesnt help the game and only is one more nail in the coffin.I jumped back in from time to time, and see whether i like the game or not.I think i got my money somehow worth considering my playingtime.But i also would deny that since i didnt enjoy playing it really and only go about half way through the game before quitting.Just not worth the time and money.
